Person1: Yeah, they're bad for your health.  I'm tryin' to look out for you...
Person2: That's cop bullshit.
Person1: Well, you're half right.  Best thing you could do for yourself right now would be to talk to me.
Person2: About what?
Person1: Every triangle I've ever seen never lasts.  Somebody's got to go.
Person2: Is this supposed to mean something to me?  What triangle?
Person1: You, Kelly, Sam.
Person2: I don't have to listen to this.  And you can't shove me around.  I have friends now...

Person1: But, Leon, I am only here for a few days.
Person2: If you don't stay with me, I'll have to continue my fight. I'll travel wherever Russian commissions are. I'll turn them all into Buljanoffs, Iranoffs, and Kopalskis. The world will be crowded with Russian restaurants. I'll depopulate Russia. Once you saved your country by going back. This time you can save it by staying here.
Person1: Well, when it is a choice between my personal interest and the good of my country, how can I waver? No one shall say Ninotchka was a bad Russian.

Person1: Nike specials. Two hundred bucks.
Person2: Two hundred bucks?? Are you crazy?

Person1: Baby, please don't... I love you.
Person2: I don't want to be a fool!... I want to look them in the eye and say, I know!
Person1: Baby, don't do this --
Person2: -- it'll help me if you'll tell me.
Person1: -- please, baby --
Person2: -- no, it'll help me, really --
Person1: How?
Person2: I'll know you've lied to me... all along. I'll know you're incapable of... love... that'll help me... not now, but eventually.

Person1: I just think you should'a kept him off me, that's all.
Person2: The hell are you talkin' about?
Person1: Now see? Don't do that. I'll go along with all you say about me. But that... you can't pretend no more on that. Cuz I was just a kid, Momma.  I didn't know about any of that stuff he was doin' to me.  And you let him do it. Some big nobody in your life... and you let him do as he wanted... with the only SOMEBODY you had.

Person1: I really do think it's the best night of my life.
Person2: We didn't do nothin' special I can remember. Just talked, is all.
Person1: Talkin's good. Long as you got the other? I'm a big believer in talkin', case you ain't noticed.
Person2: Too bad they don't give an award for talkin'... You'd win first prize. Especially with those tits.
Person1: You think so, baby? Does my talkin' bother you, honey?
Person2: No, I like gettin' up around four a.m. and talkin' bout wild animals... Though you woke me up this time in the middle of a dream. I kinda wish I didn't remember it. Up at Pee Dee, I couldn't remember any of my dreams.
Person1: What was this one?
Person2: It wasn't no fun, Lula. The wind was blowin' super-hard and I wasn't dressed warm. Only instead of freezin', I was sweatin' strong.

Person1: Shit no, it'll be twice cost.
Person2: You capitalist pig!
Person1: The performance is free what more do you want....I've set that old phone up as a donation box and I'll get Jahn to write out a sign....Okay, let's get going.

Person1: Huh?  Well, you know what? Now, I want you to tell me. I mean, my wife comes to me and asks me for twenty-five thousand. I mean, what do you want? Do you want a coat?
Person2: No.
Person1: Well, if you want a coat, you got it. You know that. It's not the money, it's just why do you want it?  That's all I'm askin'. Am I not entitled to that?
Person2: Look - Sam, I've been independent my whole life. I never had to ask anybody for anything. Now you're making me beg you for this.
Person1: What are you talkin' a- ?
Person2: Okay? And you're embarrassing me. Why do want to make me feel so bad?
Person1: You're askin' me for twenty-five thousand. I'm not out to make you feel bad. I want to just be able to trust you. You now, it's about trust. I have to be able to trust you with my life. Do you understand? Can I trust you?  Can I trust you?... Can I trust you?... Answer me. Can I trust you?
Person2: You can trust me.
Person1: Good, so then you could tell me what the money is for.

Person1: Well, the light caught the side of his face for a second. And it looked like he had a gray beard, maybe... late fifties, early sixties.
Person2: So you're telling me it was one guy with six guns? And he was a senior citizen?
Person1: I think it's better if we find this man before he finds us again.
Person2: I'll see what I can do. How do I get in touch with you?
Person1: We're going to hit Poppa Joe tonight, right in the comfort of his own home. Then we move on to New York. It's getting a bit hot for us here.
Person2: Be careful.
Person1: I'll call you tonight, afterwards.

Person1: Would you mind repeating the question?
Person2: Look, Baxter, I'm not stupid. I know everything that goes on in this building -- in every department -- on every floor -- every day of the year.
Person1: You do?
Person2: In 1957, we had an employee here, name of Fowler. He was very popular, too. Turned out he was running a bookie joint right in the Actuarial Department tying up the switchboard, figuring the odds on our I.B.M. machines -- so the day before the Kentucky Derby, I called in the Vice Squad and we raided the thirteenth floor.
Person1: The Vice Squad?
Person2: That's right, Baxter.
Person1: What -- what's that got to do with me? I'm not running any bookie joint.
Person2: What kind of joint are you running?
Person1: Sir?
Person2: There's a certain key floating around the office -- from Kirkeby to Vanderhof to Eichelberger to Dobisch -- it's the key to a certain apartment -- and you know who that apartment belongs to?
Person1: Who?
Person2: Loyal, cooperative, resourceful C. C. Baxter.
Person1: Oh.
Person2: Are you going to deny it?
Person1: No, sir. I'm not going to deny it. But if you'd just let me explain --
Person2: You better.
Person1: Well, about six months ago -- I was going to night school, taking this course in Advanced Accounting -- and one of the guys in our department -- he lives in Jersey -- he was going to a banquet at the Biltmore -- his wife was meeting him in town, and he needed someplace to change into a tuxedo -- so I gave him the key    and word must have gotten around -- because the next thing I knew, all sorts of guys were suddenly going to banquets -- and when you give the key to one guy, you can't say no to another and the whole thing got out of hand -- pardon me.

Person1: I've got some good news.  The doctor says you're all better.  You can come home.
Person2: Really?  I don't feel so great.
Person1: No, you look good.  And the tests came back fine.  C'mon...

Person1: Never play with someone's else's cards. You always get a new deck. Look at this card. See anything?
Person2: It is just a regular card.
Person1: Son, I can take everything you got with that deck. It is marked. Now I'm going to show you how to make some money in case you get stuck somewhere.

Person1: Hello?
Person2: We got disconnected before....
Person1: No. No. We got disconnect -- why?.....you're calling me at work....how did you get this number -- ?
Person2: See the thing is I could make it really easy on you -- I already have your credit card number, your information, address and stuff. This is so awkward asking like this, I'm sorry --
Person1: This makes me very uncomfortable.
Person2: I need help.
Person2: Should I just ask your girlfriend?  Maybe I should call back and talk to your girlfriend?
Person1: I don't have a girlfriend --
Person2: -- you said you did.
Person1: I know I did. But I don't.
Person2: You lied to me?
Person1: I didn't lie.
Person2: Why did you tell me you did, then?
Person1: This is....illegal....I'll call the police.
Person2: No you won't.

Person1: Look, old man, you stay out of this. We spend a fortune on you, more than we can possibly afford, and all you do is criticize, morning to night. And then you think you can -
Person2: Stanzi!
Person1: No, it's right he should hear. I'm sick to death of it. We can't do anything right for you, can we?

Person1: We're recruiting.
Person2: Who's recruiting?
Person1: Don't be clever with me, Henryk. I've come here as a friend. They're bringing Jews in from all over the country. Soon there'll be half a million people in the ghetto. We need more Jewish police...
Person2: Oh? More Jewish police? You mean you want me to wear a cap like yours, beat up Jews with my truncheon and catch the Gestapo spirit. I see!
Person1: Someone's got to do it, Henryk.
Person2: But why me? I thought you only recruited boys with rich fathers. Look at my father, look at us, I mean...
Person1: Yes, I'm looking at you and that's why I'm here. Your whole family can have a better life. You want to go on struggling for survival, selling books on the street?
Person2: Yes, please.
Person1: I'm doing you people a favour. And what about you, Wladek? You're a great pianist. And we've got an excellent police jazz band. They'd welcome you with open arms. Join us. You've got no work...

Person1: Paul, I know you've been out.
Person2: What?
Person1: You've been out of your room.
Person2: No, I haven't.
Person1: Paul, my little ceramic penguin in the study always faces due south.
Person2: I don't know what you're talking about.

Person1: This whole week has gone sour. It isn't turning out like it was supposed to.  I want to go home.
Person2: Who's being selfish now? I'm the one getting married. I thought this week was supposed to be about me.
Person1: We gotta slow down.  I'm so tired. Let's just get out of here.
Person2: I know what you need.

Person1: The rest of the jewelry is in the top drawer.
Person2: It's yours, Joe.  I gave it to you.
Person1: And I'd take it in a second, Norma -- only it's a little too dressy for sitting behind the copy desk in Dayton, Ohio.
Person2: These are nothing.  You can have anything you want if you'll only stay.  What is it you want -- money?
Person1: Norma, you'd be throwing it away. I don't qualify for the job, not any more.
Person2: You can't do this!  Max!  Max! ... I can't face life without you, and I'm not afraid to die, you know.
Person1: That's between you and yourself, Norma.
Person2: You think I made that up about the gun...

Person1: By the way, Jeffrey, this story isn't going to the press and I'm going to ask you to consider all you've heard strictly confidential. Do not discuss this business with anyone, but me, or other police personnel. Got it?
Person2: Got it. Thanks for letting me in on as much as you did.
Person1: Come on. I'll drive you home. It's on my way.

Person1: I didn't mean to hurt you.
Person2: Shhhhhh. Now I have your disease.
Person1: You what?
Person2: You put your disease in me. Your semen. It's hot and full of disease.
Person1: There's no disease, I can tell you.
Person2: Men are crazy. Then they put their craziness into me. Then it makes me crazy. Then they aren't so crazy for awhile. Then they put their craziness in me again.  It's burning me, but I love you. I do, I do. Did you know that? Did you know that I love you?
Person1: I'm glad you do.
Person2: There's so much I want to tell you. I'm in so much darkness though with things moving. There is darkness sucking me. It's kissing me and darkness is entering me. In every hole. It's opening me to a death.
Person1: Dorothy. No!
Person2: If I die, then they'll be free. It's getting late, isn't it? I can tell, it's a cold feeling when it's late. It's warm then it gets cold. Jeffrey. I feel it getting cold.
Person1: You called me Jeffrey.
Person2: I did. Are you?
Person1: Yes.
Person2: Why are you here?  HMMMMMMMM!!!! OK.
Person1: No. Not really.  But also because I really want you to be alright.

Person1: You idiot! Why do you think I use you?... To be a walking advertisement.
Person2: I'm sorry, Mike. I never heard of LaMarra flipping on anyone before. He said he had the cops paid off. Antonucci never flipped on anyone before. He had the cops paid off.
Person1: Not the cop that showed up at my door!
Person2: What happened, Mike.
Person1: You don't want to know.

Person1: Where do you think you're going?
Person2: Let go o' me! I've got to get Bruce out of jail! Oh, Walter, why did you have to do this to me?
Person1: Get Bruce out of jail! How can you worry about a man who's resting comfortably in a quiet police station while this is going on? Hildy, this is war! You can't desert now!
Person2: Oh, get off that trapeze!  There's your story! Smear it all over the front page -- Earl Williams caught by the Morning Post! And take all the credit -- I covered your story for you and I got myself in a fine mess doing it -- and now I'm getting out! I know I told you that twice before today -- but this time I mean it!
Person1: You drooling idiot! What do you mean, you're getting out! There are three hundred and sixty-five days in the year one can get married -- but how many times have you got a murderer locked up in a desk? -- Once in a lifetime! Hildy, you've got the whole city by the seat of the pants!
Person2: I know, but --
Person1: You know! You've got the brain of a pancake! That wasn't just a story you covered -- it was a revolution! Hildy! This is the greatest yarn in journalism since Livingstone discovered Stanley for the New York Herald!
Person2: Wait a minute -- wasn't it Stanley who discovered Livingstone?
Person1: Don't get technical at a time like this! Do you realize what you've done? You've taken a city that's been graft-ridden for forty years under the same old gang and with this yarn you're kicking 'em out and giving us a chance to have the same kind of government that New York's having under La Guardia! We'll make such monkeys out of these ward-heelers next Tuesday that nobody'll vote for them -- not even their wives!
Person2: I'd like to think.
Person1: Well, think it then, because it's true! We'll crucify that mob. We're going to keep Williams under cover till morning so the Post can break the story exclusive. Then we'll let the Governor in on the capture -- share the glory with him.
Person2: I get it!
Person1: You've kicked over the whole City Hall like an apple-cart. You've got the Mayor and Hartman backed against a wall. You've put one administration out and another in. This isn't a newspaper story -- it's a career! And you stand there belly-aching about whether you catch an eight o'clock train or a nine o'clock train! Still a doll-faced mugg! That's all you are.
Person2: Let me get at that typewriter and I'll show you how a doll-faced mugg can write!
Person1: Attagirl! Why, they'll be naming streets after you -- Hildy Johnson Street! There'll be statues of you in the parks, Hildy. The radio'll be after you -- the movies!  By tomorrow morning I'll betcha there's a Hildy Johnson cigar! I can see the billboards now. Light up with Hildy Johnson!
Person2: Whoa -- wait a minute. We can't leave Williams here. One of the other fellows'll --
Person1: We're going to take him over to my private office.  Where's our phone?

Person1: It'll only take a second.

Person1: I thought I told everybody to get out of my house. That includes cocksuckers and retards. Get off your asses and go.
Person2: This is not your house, Doyle. This is my house and I'll say who stays and goes. You've got a house, why don't you go get one of your girlfriends and go home to it.

Person1: My fault!  My fault!  This nut case goes out on a ledge and it's my fault?
Person2: If anything happens to John BUbber, Mister LaPlante I'm going to see you prosecuted to the full extent of the law.
Person1: What, is everybody in love with this, bozo?  I don't get this.  What about...?
Person2: Yes, everybody is in love with John Bubber.  The whole country, in fact. And they're not going to be happy if he jumps to his death because he was harassed by a lousy little money-grubbing low-life fence...
Person1: "Harassed."  Cause I yelled at him when he's riding in his limo?  The guy's a thief, he took my...
Person2: He had one tiny, uncharacteristic moment of weakness.  That's not the same thing as a lifetime of petty crime...
Person1: Hey, lady, I got faults, I know I'm not perfect but I don't get this at all, your attitude.  I saved your...
Person2: A lifetime of petty crime climaxed by your sleaziest accomplishment yet...  blackmailing a national hero...
Person1: -- saved your...  whaaaaaaat?  What? Blackmailing...?
Person2: You think I haven't figured it out? Just because the cops aren't on to you yet doesn't mean you're home free.  I'm a veteran reporter.  I've seen your kind before, the underbelly of crime.
Person1: Underbelly!
Person2: In all that smoke and fire, John had a moment of weakness.  He'd been down and out, destitute, living in his car.  It was just an impulse, stealing my purse.

Person1: Look...we're all tired.  None of us had any sleep since Friday night...
Person2: That's the only reason you're alive...

Person1: I am prepared to do that anyway.

Person1: Bill, I...
Person2: DON'T SAY "BILL," BERNIE!  DON'T SAY ONE WORD!  DIDN'T I SAY "ONE WORD AND YOU'RE FIRED?"
Person1: I...
Person2: YOU KNOW WHY?  BECAUSE IT'LL BE AN EXCUSE!  IT'LL BE "BERNIE LAPLANTE EXCUSE NUMBER FOUR THOUSAND ONE HUNDRED AND SIX."  NO, FOUR THOUSAND ONE HUNDRED AND TWELVE.  THAT'S HOW MANY EXCUSES YOU HAVE GIVEN ME, I KEEP TRACK OF THEM ELECTRONICALLY. I HEARD THEM ALL, BERNIE.
Person1: Bill, I got some legal problems and I...
Person2: THAT'S IT!  YOU TALKED!  YOU'RE FIRED!  OUTTA HERE!  GET OUTTA HERE!
Person1: Bill, listen...

Person1: Bill, I got financial problems and...
Person2: I DON'T CARE ABOUT YOUR PROBLEMS, I'M GONNA THINK ABOUT MY PROBLEMS. YOU'RE ONE A MY PROBLEMS.  GET OUT! OUT!  OUT!

Person1: See that wasn't so bad.

Person1: How could she have done this to me? How could anyone do this to anyone?
Person2: You didn't say anything about my hair.

Person1: You got it.  Operation Deflower Mayflower is a bad joke and I'm the punchline.  I thought we were using the CIA to help us to get Mayflower, but really the CIA was using me to keep us away from Mayflower.
Person2: Oh, why couldn't I be the Cardinal in charge of catering.... If the Mayflowers get the three sections of Da Vinci's crystal and his instructions for the gold machine-- Aie-yi--Do we got anything?  What of Alex, Hawk's friend, where is his loyalty?

Person1: You know Rach, Discount Mart is having a sale on Halloween costumes.
Person2: No. Brady's working there till 6:00 today.

Person2: I don't want to look pushy.
Person1: You won't look pushy.
Person2: Well I don't want to come on too strong. A guy hates a girl to come on strong. Fragile egos and all of that.
Person1: You won't come on too strong.
Person2: Well I don't want to seem desperate or anything.
Person1: Fact it Rach, you are desperate.  Your just going to go in and buy a costume for Jamie. Perfectly legit.
Person2: I don't know.
Person1: Well do I drop you off at the Discount Mart or the Dairy Queen?
Person2: Jamie?

Person1: No, hang on, I've not gone daft. You see, when I was little me mother let me make some treacle toffee one time in our back scullery. When I'd done she said to me, "Go and give some to the other kids." So, I said I would but I thought to meself, "She must think I'm soft." Anyroad, I was eating away there but I wanted somebody else to know how good it was so in the end I wound up giving it all away ... but I didn't mind, mind, 'cos I'd made the stuff in the first place. Well ... that's why you need other people... an audience ... to taste your treacle toffee, like. Eh ... does that sound as thickheaded to you as it does to me?
Person2: Not really but I'm probably not a toffee maker. How would you do those lines of mine?
Person1: Well, look at it this way, I mean, when you come right down to it, that girl, she's a bit of a scrubber, isn't she?
Person2: Is she?
Person1: Of course ... Look, if she was a Liverpool scrubber ...  Eh, fella, you want to try pulling the other one, it's got a full set of bells hanging off it ... Y'what? ... I know your sort, two cokes and a packet of cheese and onion crisps and suddenly it's love and we're stopping in an empty shop doorway. You're just after me body and y'can't have it ... so there!!
Person2: And you honestly think that's what she meant?
Person1: Oh, definitely, it sticks out a mile, she's trying to get him to marry her but he doesn't want ... well ... I don't reckon any fella's ever wanted to get married. But girls are like that, clever and cunning. You've got to laugh.

Person1: 'Scuse me.
Person2: I know it can't be easy. Life hasn't changed that much for Reed, Sue and Johnny. At least they can go out in public. But for you? People staring. Whispering behind your back...
Person1: If you're trying to cheer me up you're doing a helluva job --
Person2: I'm just saying, I know what it's like to lose something you love. To see it slip away, and know it's never coming back.

Person1: You said you were going to get her out of this.

Person2: I'd love to.  But he keeps showing up.  And you keep talking to him.  I can't have that--

Person1: We're damaged goods.
Person2: No, we're not!
Person1: We are, Miles. You know I'm right. There's something "off" about you and me Miles. And maybe it isn't because of these women -- maybe they were just extremely insightful and recognized our "deficiencies" very early on. Maybe...
Person2: That is bullshit! Mine is a bitch and yours is a psycho. I can't believe you're saying this, Marylin! There's nothing wrong with us. We're attractive and charismatic and successful and... I like us.
Person1: I'm sorry Miles. You shouldn't listen to me. I'm sure you have a very fulfilling life. I'd better go. I'm depressing.
Person2: No.
Person1: Thank you for the coffee. It's very robust.

Person1: You killed them.
Person2: It was only a matter of time before somebody killed somebody.  You saw it coming as well as I did. Dodge had his plans, starting with scuttling the boat. And Greer too, except he went nuts. Couldn't take it, I guess. Could've happened in the middle of downtown Anchorage. But did it make him any less dangerous? I don't think so.
Person1: So you killed them?
Person2: The way I figure it, it was them or me. I thought putting Dodge up on that pipe was a nice touch? Bought a little time. Made it look like whoever killed those Greeks was still around. But it's just us on this ship. Us and your... spirit friends.
Person1: And now you're gonna kill me, is that it?
Person2: I didn't want it to turn out this way.
Person1: Murphy, don't you see what's happening?
Person2: I think I see it pretty well.
Person1: It's the ship. The ship's making you think this way.
Person2: I know a little bit about human nature and what I've seen only confirms that.
Person1: It's a trap. There was no way we were gonna get away with that gold. Nobody ever does. It's just the bait. This ship sucks people in and it never lets them out.
Person2: I think maybe you been on this boat a little too long, with all that supernatural mumbo jumbo. There's nothing supernatural about greed. And that's what it comes down to, pure and simple.
Person1: I don't give a damn about the gold.
Person2: I wish I could believe that. Either way, you know what I've done. I've got no choice.

Person1: You'll never have another chance to hit me again.  I never knew till this minute -
Person2: Susan, it seems to me -

Person2: No, you're not.
Person1: Yes.

Person1: Okay.   Okay.    I believe you.

Person2: Bullshit! She was alive when we left her with you.

Person1: Now, if you'll excuse me, I really must...
Person2: Wait. Stop. You don't seem to understand. You're not really comprehending any of this. I killed him. I did it, Carnes. I'm Patrick Bateman. I chopped Owen's head off. I tortured dozens of girls. The whole message I left on your machine was true.

Person2: No! Listen, don't you know who I am? I'm not Davis, I'm Patrick Bateman! I talk to you on the phone all the time! Don't you recognize me? You're my lawyer.

Person1: Just for curiosity sake that's all?

Person1: Now, let's free ourselves from emotionalism and try to solve the problem in a practical way. Our situation has changed considerably. Before I had only a claim to the jewels. Now I have the jewels.
Person2: In other words moral ideas have no weight with you... all right, then let's deal with legal facts. You know that France has recognized the Soviet.
Person1: Unfortunately.
Person2: Under Soviet law the jewels belong to the State. France is going to uphold that ownership.
Person1: My lawyer agrees with you. He says France will uphold it in every court, but I will drag you through every court, don't forget that. And when I say it will take two years I am, as always, conservative.
Person2: Won't those two years in court be expensive for you? I know that money was no object as long as you could squeeze it from the pockets of the people, but now...
Person1: I may run out of money, but you have already run out of bread. Two years is a long time for your comrades to wait.
Person2: I see. You have calculated in terms of hunger.
Person1: No, I just wanted to be absolutely impartial. Both of us are faced with two rather uncomfortable years. We can condense these two years to two minutes if you want to accept my proposition. Ninotchka now realizes what she is after.
Person2: Go on.
Person1: I am willing to hand over the jewels and sign the necessary papers if you take that five-forty plane to Moscow.
Person2: That's not the way to win him back... not Leon.
Person1: I think I know Leon quite as well as you... possibly a little better. Leave that worry to me. Five-forty leaves you time enough to close the deal with Monsieur Mercier, but naturally you'll be too busy for any farewells. I'll see to it that everything is done in the most expeditious manner and I will also see you to the airport. That's my proposition, Comrade Yakushova.

Person1: Now I'm the one who's nauseous. So what's the deal? What do you need me for?
Person2: There's some folks I want to keep tabs on. Dirty, tattooed, uncivilized. Your kind of people.
Person1: What do I get out of it?
Person2: If you find out what I want to know, and if I'm able to successfully use that information, you get to go back to your degenerate little life. If not, you take a bath.
Person1: You're one sick bastard. A sadist with a badge looking to rope me in to a suicide mission. I think no matter which way I go I'm likely to wind up face down on a sheet of plastic. So here's my answer

Person1: What are you?
Person2: You know.
Person1: You want me to believe you're the Devil, well, I don't, that's bullshit!
Person2: I'm not the Devil.
Person1: Then what, what are you? Tell me...
Person2: Better if I just show you.

Person1: They've taken my mind, my memories...
Person2: What?  Who has?

Person2: What is going on?

Person1: Why? Why? Why? Why add to your misery by confessing to murder? You didn't kill him.
Person2: I did.
Person1: No, you didn't!
Person2: I poisoned his life.
Person1: But not his body.
Person2: What difference does that make?
Person1: My son, why should you want all Vienna to believe you a murderer? Is that your penance? Is it?
Person2: No, Father. From now on no one will be able to speak of Mozart without thinking of me. Whenever they say Mozart with love, they'll have to say Salieri with loathing. And that's my immortality - at last! Our names will  be tied together for eternity - his in fame and mine in infamy. At least it's better than the total oblivion he'd planned for me, your merciful God!
Person1: Oh my son, my poor son!
Person2: Don't pity me. Pity yourself. You serve a wicked God. He killed Mozart, not I. Took him, snatched him away, without pity. He destroyed His beloved rather than let a mediocrity like me get the smallest share in his glory. He doesn't care. Understand that. God cares nothing for the man He denies and nothing either for the man He uses. He broke Mozart in half when He'd finished with him, and threw him away. Like an old, worn out flute.

Person1: What are you crazy kids doing in my tool shed?
Person2: We're not crazy. We're "special". PRINCIPAL COLLINS wants us to have our own classroom!
Person1: My boy's special, well how about that. I knew you were different.
Person2: So I guess you'll need a new spot for your moonshine.
Person1: I reckon so.

Person1: If Corbett's men find out --
Person2: -- I'm putting him on the plane to Fairbanks, eleven tomorrow.
Person1: Jiminy Christmas.  What do you want from me?
Person2: Corbett ruined my two-way.  Go to my place on the Haul Road, tell Anne Marie I'm okay and to sit tight.

Person1: You will not be unaware of the threat now posed by Republicanism.
Person2: Why do you think I keep her here?
Person1: Ah, but therein lies the paradox.  It is her very isolation that encourages the malcontents.  The longer she is away, the stronger they become; and who, honestly, can promise security against that?  However many doors you lock, someone will always get in. Even here.

Person1: You made your decision yet?
Person2: I'm leaning toward no.
Person1: That's your option.  Ours could be to keep you locked up for a very long time.  In case you didn't know it, you're crazy.

Person1: Hi, hello, great.  This is Seduce and Destroy?
Person2: It is.  Can I have your home phone number with area code?
Person1: Well I don't want to order anything, you see. I have a situation, a situation just come up that's really pretty serious and I'm not sure who I should talk to or what I should do but could you maybe put me in touch with the right person if I explain myself?
Person2: I'm really only equipped to take orders --
Person1: Well can you connect me to someone else?
Person2: Well what's the situation?
Person1: Well, ok.  Lemme see how I explain this without it seeming kinda crazy, but here go: I'm, my name is Phil Parma and I work for a man named Earl Partridge -- Mr. Earl Partidge. I'm his nurse.  He's a very sick man. He's a dying man and he's sick and he's asked me to help him, to help him find his son -- Hello?  Are you there, hello?
Person2: I'm here, I'm listening.
Person1: OK.  See. Frank TJ Macky is Earl Partridge's son....

Person1: A name. Grunemann. Nothing. And they showed me pictures like this and they meant nothing. Then they asked me, well had I been getting letters, from someone out there in Cabbageville --
Person2: -- Tuscarora --
Person1: All right, yes, I had been. Those sick, wild letters -- I'm watching you, gonna follow you, gonna punish you, kill you et cetera. Well, they said, all right that's Grunemann. So try to remember when you and he - when -- well I don't know, there was that dumper once, he sounded like that dumper --  Dumpers; they get their kicks beating you up. A man hired me once, then tried to really kill me - that'd be about two years ago.

Person1: Do you have any idea how goddamn crazy you are?
Person2: You mean the nature of this conversation?
Person1: I mean the nature of you.

Person1: I'm the only goddamn person in there pulling for you.
Person2: You humiliated me!
Person1: No, Maggie, I defended you. Humiliating you is what everyone else is doing.  It's the theme of this party.
Person2: I had it under control.  Now they feel sorry for me.
Person1: Well, they should.  Because they're about to watch you hang yourself again.

Person1: Oh, I was going to discover the secret of the universe.  That's why I liked Nix.  He promised me all these explanations.
Person2: And he didn't have them?
Person1: He had something.  He showed me how to bend the rules.  A little levitation.  A few fireworks.
Person2: Is that all?
Person1: No.  At the end... when we had him cornered, he got into my head. He showed me what we really look like, when the veneer's gone.  Jelly. Shit...
Person2: And you believed him?
Person1: I saw it with my own eyes! See, that's his best trick.  No illusions.  Just the truth.  Are you ready for that?

Person2: I didn't say shit.

Person1: I got your message... But you went right to Johnnie, didn't you?... I can't trust you, bitch - not for one minute... Naughty girl... Sailor and Lula are headed west, and guess what? There's no turning back. I'm in a killing mood.
Person2: No...
Person1: My very best to Johnnie... Bless his soul.

Person1: We can at least fight -- we might be able to kill a few--
Person2: Will -- it'll go worse for us -- for Elizabeth, especially -- if we fight.

Person1: Or what if there really was an error? -- I don't know what kind -- any kind that needed correcting -- and what if Burgel was responsible for it?  One mistake -- even a small one in a firm like ours -- it could cost him a promotion.
Person2: First these nameless authorities were the root of all evil, now it's insignificant Burgel.  If indeed there was a mistake -- and a minor one at that -- you're suggesting someone went to a lot of trouble over something so trivial as to not matter at all.

Person1: The look on your face!  You're not marriage material.  You're not even boyfriend material.  You're a kid. A big, fun, slightly irresponsible kid.
Person2: I'm not a kid.
Person1: What are you then?  What will you be ten years from now?  Still cutting lawns?  Still banging horny divorcees in your trailer?

Person1: You're better when you take them.

Person1: All right.  How about I feel better when you take them?

Person1: There's a couple of points I keep wondering about have to do with the two guys that grabbed you.  Buddy is it?  And this fella Jack Foley.  I swear the man must've robbed two hundred banks in his time.
Person2: Really?  Huh.  He told me he didn't remember how many he robbed.
Person1: You talked to him?
Person2: In the trunk, yeah?
Person1: What'd you talk about?
Person2: Oh... different things, prison, movies.
Person1: This fella holds you hostage, you talk about movies?
Person2: It was an unusual experience.
Person1: Foley made me think of that fella Carl Tillman, the one you were seeing, it turns out the same time he was doing banks.  You recall that?
Person2: When I was seeing Carl Tillman, I didn't know he robbed banks.
Person1: Yeah, but I had enough reason to believe he did, and I told you.  So you had to at least suspect him.
Person2: And what happened to Carl?
Person1: The time came, you shot him.  But you didn't shoot Foley or the guy with him.  They're unarmed, you had a shotgun and you let them throw you in the trunk. Okay, now you got your Sig in your hand.  You say in the report you couldn't turn around, he had you pinned down.  But when the trunk opened, how come you didn't cap the two guys then?
Person2: Is that what you would've done?
Person1: You say in the report Glenn didn't have a gun, but you let him get away, too.
Person2: Daniel, what do you work on most of the time, fraud?  Go after crooked bookkeepers.
Person1: Karen, I've been with the Bureau fifteen years, on all kinds of investigations.
Person2: Have you ever shot a man?  How many times have you been primary through the door?
Person1: I have to qualify, is that it?
Person2: You have to know what you're talking about.

Person1: It'll take hours.  You can't make me do this.

Person1: Mummy and I, we were more like lovers, really, or sisters.  Then a couple of years after Daddy died, and not long after I left Oxford, she started seeing various men and I was furious.  I really was upset. I stopped going home.  I never phoned.  I went round telling everyone how awful her books were. And she hardly seemed to notice, and that made me angrier.  Then I got a job I was interested in, and I started to see lots of men, and I suppose I grew up a little and began to understand.  So I wrote her a long letter, almost seven pages, saying how sorry I was, and how I was worried that we were drifting apart.  And do you know, she wrote me a poem, a really beautiful poem about mothers and daughters.
Person2: How nice.

One million, four hundred and ten thousand dollars.  But if you were to dock my salary, say, twenty dollars a week, in a few hundred years we'd be even... and I think this is where you fire me?

Person1: They found another note?
Person2: Uh-huh. Another News clipping. Another one about Sid's mom. Dewey, whether we like it  or not it looks like we're going to have to  go back into our past.
Person1: You mean OUR past as in Me and Sid. This has nothing to do with you Gale.
Person2: This has everything to do with me Dewey. I was the one who brought the nation's attention to this shit anyway. I'll be damned if I'm gonna sit around and pass on the buck again.
Person1: Do you really mean it this time Gale?
Person2: Yes. Look, let's get something straight Dewey, I got into this shit cause the police came looking for ME. Not cause I'm out to make the SUNRISE STUDIOS SLASHINGS.
Person1: Why would the police come to you?
Person2: Again, I am the author of the definitive book on the Woodsboro murders.!  What about you?
Person1: What about me?
Person2: You said you'd never leave Woodsboro, 'The only place that's real!'  But now you're here. Not with me.  Dewey, I took care of you.  I waited until you were well.  I couldn't stay there, I mean, it's like dog years, one year in Woodsboro is like seven everywhere else.
Person1: So it's off to London for a week?  New York for a month? L.A Forever?
Person2: It was '60 Minutes II'!  I couldn't say no!  I could've been the next Diane Sawyer!
Person1: What's wrong with just being Gale Weathers? I liked her!
Person2: It didn't work Dewey.  We tried,  we're different.
Person1: You used to say that was our strength.
Person2: Dewey, you're not just here because of that second rate K-Mart, straight-to-video version of me, are you?
Person1: Brace yourself, Gale, all of this is actually not About you.
Person2: All of what Dewey?  You do know something, don't you?
Person1: Off the record.
Person2: Always.
Person1: Two months ago, the Woodsboro police got a call from a woman who said she was with 'Stab 3'.  She wanted to see the file on Sid, for research.
Person2: And?
Person1: The boys said no.  She wouldn't give her name. A month later, the station gets broken into, the file room ransacked.
Person2: Someone stole Sid's file?
Person1: I already removed it.  I think someone on the film was trying to find Sid, and that's the only reason I came here. To make do a little private investigating of my own and make sure no one here was planning anything.
Person2: I'm sorry, this is too good!
Person1: What part of 'Off the record' don't you understand?
Person2: Right. Sorry.  Do you think he did it?
Person1: I've got my suspicions but still, nothing  you say can ever make me take my eyes off one person.
Person2: And who is that?

Person1: You haven't said a word since we left the club -- what happened back there?
Person2: I -- I'm not sure if I'm supposed to tell you or not.
Person1: I don't think I follow you.
Person2: He said if I told anybody it could prove fatal for them as well as me.
Person1: Who said?
Person2: That's what I'm not supposed to say.
Person1: Stop this nonsense! If you're in some sort of trouble I want to know about it.
Person2: Stop bullying me. Everybody's bullying me.
Person1: I wasn't --
Person2: Yes, you were -- you called it nonsense. Being murdered in cold blood isn't nonsense. Wait until it happens to you sometime.

Person1: Revenge is a dish best served cold... well, it's payback time, sport.  ... see that building? I bought into it ten years ago. It was my first real estate deal. I sold it a couple of years later and made an $800,000 dollar profit. It was better than sex. At that time I thought that was all tne money in the world...  Now, it's a day's pay ... I had a mole in Wildman's employ. Gave me half the picture, then he got fired...
Person2: I don't understand.
Person1: Wildman's in town. He just became an American citizen. Something big's about to go down. I want to know where he goes and who he sees. I want you, sport, to give me the missing half of the picture...
Person2: Follow him? Mr. Gekko I...  It's not what I do. I could lose my license. If the SEC found out, I could go to jail. It's inside information, isn't it?
Person1: Inside information. Oh you mean like when a father tells his son about a court ruling on an airline? Or someone overhears me saying I'm gonna buy Teldar Paper? Or the chairman of the board of XYZ suddenly knows it's time to blow out XYZ. You mean that?  I'm afraid sport, unless you got a father on the board of directors of another company, you and I are gonna have a hard time doing any business...

Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: What?
Person1: Stop acting like an infant. You're here because you want me to help you in some way. What do you need from me? You need money?
Person2: Do you still have friends on the force?
Person1: Yes, I still have friends on the force.
Person2: Could you find out if they know anythin'? I don't know they know shit about us. But I don't wanna think, I wanna know. You could find out for sure what's goin' on.  Daddy?
Person1: What makes you think I could do that?
Person2: You were a cop.
Person1: What makes you think I would do that?
Person2: I'm your son.
Person1: You got it all worked out, don't you?
Person2: Look, goddamnit, I never asked you for a goddamn thing! I've tried to make your parental obligation as easy as possible. After Mom divorced you, did I ask you for anything? When I wouldn't see ya for six months to a year at a time, did you ever get your shit about it? No, it was always "OK", "No problem", "You're a busy guy, I understand". The whole time you were a drunk, did I ever point my finger at you and talk shit? No! Everybody else did. I never did. You see, I know that you're just a bad parent. You're not really very good at it. But I know you love me. I'm basically a pretty resourceful guy. If I didn't really need it I wouldn't ask. And if you say no, don't worry about it. I'm gone. No problems.

Person2: George, I may be wrong, I may be a maniac. But I believe in this, and I'm not going to lose it.  You know how much I want to help you, but this is bigger, stronger if you like than brotherly love. I'm sorry, George. I'm staying.
Person1: Well, I can't think of anything more to say. Goodbye, Bob.

Person1: Let me worry about that, Major. I've still got my red line to the Air Command.
Person2: That's right, sir.
Person1: We don't want to be vulnerable to saboteurs calling up and pretending to be different people from the President down, do we?
Person2: You're right, sir.
Person1: No calls from inside out.  No calls from outside in are even answered.  No calls.
Person2: I understand, sir.  Nothing comes or goes without your personal say-so.
Person1: No calls at all.  With or without my say-so. My voice can be imitated too, Major.
Person2: Yes, sir.  I just thought of something, sir.  How do I know I'm talking to you now?
Person1: Who do you think you're talking to?
Person2: To you, sir.  But how do I know?
Person1: Are you trying to be insubordinate?
Person2: No, sir.
Person1: I hope not.  Now, as soon as you do what I told you, have Plan-R radioed to the Wing.
Person2: Plan-R????
Person1: Are you hard of hearing, Major?
Person2: No, sir.  Plan-R to be radioed to the Wing.
Person1: As soon as you've done that, shut down the communications center.  Lock it up and assign the personnel to base security details.
Person2: General Ripper, if I shut down the communi- cations center, there'll be no radio or teleprinter contact with Air Command head- quarters or anyone, for that matter.
Person1: Are you questioning my orders, Major?
Person2: No, sir.  I'm just bringing the facts to your attention, sir.
Person1: You're a good officer, Major, and you're perfectly right to bring these facts to my attention.
Person2: Thank you, sir.
Person1: Now, as soon as you've done that, double- up on all base security teams.  Our enemies are plenty smart, and there might even be an attack on the base by saboteurs.
Person2: Yes, sir.
Person1: And lastly, all privately owned radios are to be immediately impounded.  They can be used to issue instructions to saboteurs. Air Police will have lists of all owners.

Person1: You've always been so good to Li Mu Bai and me.  Please accept our thanks.

Person2: When it comes to emotions, even great heroes can be idiots.  Tell me if Li Mu Bai is not more open the next time you see him.  I'll give him an earful!

Person2: Well, whatta you mean? I mean, it's perfectly fine out here. I mean, Tony's very nice and, uh, well, I meet people and I go to parties and- and we play tennis. I mean, that's... that's a very big step for me, you know?  I mean...  I'm able to enjoy people more.

Person2: What's so great about New York? I mean, it's a dying city. You read "Death in Venice."
Person1: Hey, you didn't read "Death in Venice" till I bought it for yuh.
Person2: That's right, that's right.  You only gave me books with the word "death" in the titles.
Person1: That's right, 'cause it's an important issue.
Person2: Alvy, you're incapable of enjoying life, you know that? I mean, your life is New York City. You're just this person. You're like this island unto yourself.
Person1: I can't enjoy anything unless I... unless everybody is. I-you know, if one guy is starving someplace, that's... you know, I-I... it puts a crimp in my evening.  So wanna get married or what?
Person2: No. We're friends. I wanna remain friends.
Person1: Okay.  Check, please. Can I -can I... Can I... Can I...
Person2: You're mad, aren't you?
Person1: No.  Yes, of course I'm mad, because you love me, I know that.
Person2: Alvy, I can't say that that's true at this point in my life. I really just can't say that that's true. I mean, you know how wonderful you are. I mean, you know... you're the reason that I got outta my room and that I was able to sing, and-and- and, you know, get more in touch with my feelings and all that crap. Anyway, look, I don't wanna- Listen, listen, listen, uh  h'h, so whatta you up to anyway, huh?
Person1: The usual, you know. Uh, tryin' t' write. I'm workin' on a play.  Jesus. So whatta yuh saying? That you're not comin' back to New York with me?

Person1: Eddie, is it all right if I get personal?
Person2: Whaddya been so far?
Person1: Eddie, you're a born loser.
Person2: What's that supposed to mean?
Person1: First time in ten years I ever saw Minnesota Fats hooked, really hooked. But you let him off.
Person2: I told you. I got drunk.
Person1: Sure, you got drunk. That's the best excuse in the world for losing. No trouble losing when you got a good excuse. And winning! That can be heavy on your back too. Like a monkey. You drop that load too when you got an excuse. All you gotta do is learn to feel sorry for yourself. It's one of the best indoor sports: feeling sorry for yourself -- a sport enjoyed by all, especially the born losers.
Person2: Thanks for the drink.
Person1: Wait a minute. Maybe I can help you.
Person2: To do what?
Person1: Get the three thousand. Play Minnesota Fats again.
Person2: Why?
Person1: Ten reasons. Maybe fifteen. And also there's something in it for me.
Person2: Oh yeah, I figured that. How much?
Person1: Seventy-five per cent.
Person2: For who?
Person1: For me.
Person2: That's a -- that's a pretty big slice. Who do you think you are, General Motors?
Person1: How much you think you're worth these days? I'm puttin' up the money, I'm puttin' up the time. For that I get seventy-five per cent return on my money -- if you win.
Person2: You think I can lose?
Person1: I never saw you do anything else.
Person2: You saw me beat Minnesota Fats for eighteen thousand dollars.
Person1: Look, you wanna hustle pool, don't you? This game isn't like football. Nobody pays you for yardage. When you hustle you keep score real simple. The end of the game you count up your money. That's how you find out who's best. That's the only way.
Person2: Why back me then? Why not back yourself? Go find yourself a big fat poker game and get rich. You know all the angles.
Person1: I'm already rich. But I like action. That's one thing I think you're good for is action. Besides, like I say... you got talent.
Person2: Yeah, you already told me that. You cut that slice down to bite-size and maybe we can talk.
Person1: No, we don't talk. I don't make bad bets. Seventy-five, twenty-five. That's it.
Person2: Kiss off.

Person1: Well, as you know, most of my staff have weighed in against this "incursion."  They believe it will fail to achieve anything fundamental militarily, and will result in crushing criticism domestically ...

Person1: Within no time, everything was set in place. We got rid of the freelance scamsters. The per was way up.  The gods were happy, or as happy as the gods can ever be.  And I, I decided to complicate my life. For a guy who likes sure things, I was about to bet the rest of my life on a real longshot.
Person1: We're not getting any younger. Don't you think it's time? Aren't you gettin' tired of all this shit? Bangin' around, hustlin' around?
Person2: What, are you trying to handicap me?
Person1: I'm gonna do you one better. I'm trying to marry you. You want to marry me?  I'm serious. I mean, I - I want to settle down. I want a family.
Person2: You got the wrong girl, Sam.
Person1: I know I'd be a good father. I know you'd be a good mother.
Person2: You don't know me. What, you've known me, two, three months. What do you know?
Person1: I'm forty-three years old. I don't want to wait. I know you well enough to know that I really love you very much.  And I can't think of anybody better to be with. And I don't feel like waiting anymore.
Person2: You know a lot of happily married people, Sam? 'Cause I don't.
Person1: Yeah, I know all that.
Person2: I care about you, a - But I just don't have those kind of feelings for you. I'm sorry. I'm not in love with you.
Person1: I - I - I...
Person2: Understand?  I'm sorry.
Person1: No, I - I... mean...  that can grow as I - as long as there's a mutual respect... that kind of thing can grow. I'm realistic. I can accept that. But, you know, what is... What is love anyway?  It's a... it's a mutual respect. It's - it's a devotion. It's a... it's a caring from one person to another. And if we could set up some kind of foundation...  based on that mutual respect...  I feel that eventually you would care enough about me... that I could live with that.
Person2: If it doesn't work out. You know, if it doesn't play out, then what happens to me?
Person1: You know I'm doin' well now. And I'm gonna do even better. And so, whatever happens, if it doesn't work out between us, I'm gonna make sure you're okay for the rest of your life. And if there are kids, especially, you know, I'll take care of you better than you'd ever imagine.
Person2: What're you... what're you pitching me, here?
Person1: Just what I said. You'll be set up for the rest of your life. That I can promise you.  Want to take a chance?

Person1: Oh please, who do you think you're kidding? And where did she spy on the Russians from, here in Pennsylvania??
Person2: No, not here in Pennsylvania, she went to Russia undercover with her acting troupe and got a lot of highly sensitive secret plans sent back. Just when she was about to go home, she got caught, and they killed her.
Person1: All right, so when did she have you between all her acting and spying and getting caught?
Person2: That's simple. She was pregnant with me...when she went to Russia and she didn't know...and then when the Russians found out, they waited to shoot her 'cause you're not allowed to kill pregnant women anywhere in the world.

Person1: They buried my ma & pa and my sisters. And Chingachgook - who found me with two French trappers - raised me up as his own.
Person2: I'm sorry.
Person1: I do not remember them. I was one or two.
Person2: How did you learn English?
Person1: My father sent Uncas & I to Reverend Wheelock's school when I was ten. So we would know both worlds... though we were told only bother learning readin' & arithmetic from yours.
Person2: And what were the consequentialities of European culture you didn't bother with?
Person1: The Bible. Monarchy. Many wrong ideas about the government of men. My father's people already know each man is his own nation. And only he can have dominion over himself. Not kings. No man is better than any other man.
Person2: In London those radical ideas could land you in Newgate prison.  Why were those people living in this defenseless place...?
Person1: 'Cos frontier land's the only land affordable to poor people. So after seven years indentured service in Virginia, they headed out here where they are beholden to none and not livin' by another's leave...  Their name was Cameron. John & Alexandria.

Person1: ...he's a good man...
Person2: ...he's a good man...?  He's the Prince of Darkness...he'll have people in there testifying that the broad is well -- they saw her Tuesday on a surfboard at Hyannis...don't mess with this case.

Person2: Frank, but not now.  Frank.  You're trying to wipe out some old business.  But not now.  I understand.  But you go call 'em back.  You call the Bishop back.

Person1: You should shit or get off the pot.
Person2: I should shit or get off the pot.
Person1: Yeah, you should shit or get off the pot.
Person2: What are you talking about?
Person1: I'm talking about this thing you have... this inability to improve your situation in life.
Person2: Forget you.
Person1: It's true. You'll sit there and blame life for dealing a cruddy hand, never once accepting the responsibility for the way your situation is.
Person2: What responsibility?
Person1: All right, if you hate this job and the people, and the fact that you have to come in on your day off, then quit.
Person2: As if it's that easy.
Person1: It is. You just up and quit. There are other jobs, and they pay better money. You're bound to be qualified for at least one of them. So what's stopping you?
Person2: Leave me alone.
Person1: You're comfortable. This is a life of convenience for you, and any attempt to change it would shatter the pathetic microcosm you've fashioned for yourself.
Person2: Oh, like your life's any better?
Person1: I'm satisfied with my situation for now. You don't hear me bitching. You, on the other hand, have been bitching all day.
Person2: Thank you. Why don't you go back to the video store?
Person1: It's the same thing with Veronica.
Person2: Leave her out of this.
Person1: You date Veronica because she's low maintenance and because it's convenient. Meanwhile, all you ever do is talk about Caitlin. You carry a torch for a girl you dated in high school-in high school for God's sake! You're twenty-two!
Person2: Leave me alone.
Person1: If you want Caitlin, then face Veronica, tell her, and be with Caitlin. If you want Veronica, be with Veronica. But don't pine for one and be with the other. Man, if you weren't such a coward...
Person2: ...If I wasn't such a coward.  It must be so great to be able to simplify everything the way you do.
Person1: Am I right or what?
Person2: You're wrong. Things happened today, okay? Things that probably ruined my chances with Caitlin.
Person1: What? The dead guy?  She'll get over fucking the dead guy. Shit, my mom's been fucking a dead guy for thirty years; I call him Dad.
Person2: Caitlin and I can't be together. It's impossible.
Person1: Melodrama coming from you seems about as natural as an oral bowel movement.
Person2: What do you want me to say? Yes, I suppose some of the things you're saying may be true. But that's the way things are; it's not going to change.
Person1: Make them change.
Person2: I can't, all right! Jesus, would you leave me alone? I can't make changes like that in my life. If I could, I would-but I don't have the ability to risk comfortable situations on the big money and the fabulous prizes.
Person1: Who're you kidding? You can so.
Person2: Jesus H. Christ, I can't!
Person1: So you'll continue being miserable all the time, just because you don't have the guts to face change?
Person2: My mother told me once that when I as three, my potty lid was closed, and instead of lifting it, I chose to shit my pants.
Person1: Lovely story.
Person2: Point is-I'm not the kind of person that disrupts things in order to shit comfortably.

Person1: So, how did you learn that the Gestapo was out to get you?
Person2: During an enforced hour-long interval because of a power failure at a concert here in Berlin, Albert Speer, the Minister of Armaments, said to me, 'You look very tired Dr. Furtwngler, you should go abroad for a while.' I knew exactly what he meant.
Person1: You sure knew a lot of people in high places.
Person2: It would be truer to say, I think, that a lot of people in high places knew me.
Person1: You were real close to all of them, to Adolf, to Hermann, to Joseph, to Baldur, and now Albert,  So, let's hear the truth, let's come clean. What was your Party number?
Person2: If you are going to bully me like this, Major, you had better do your homework. You obviously have no idea how impertinent and stupid your questions are.

Person1: Is that really what you want?
Person2: I want to stop taking those pills.
Person1: I wish you wouldn't.
Person2: They do something to me.  It's hard to think straight.
Person1: I think they help.
Person2: I have consciousness, but I am not mortal.  Don't you see why I'm going crazy?
Person1: You have to remember that I love you, that's all that matters --
Person2: I can't --
Person1: It put you here.  I'll admit it, it acted like a God and put you here, put you into my consciousness.  I was asleep, and it put you into my dream.  I saw your mouth.  And there you were.  Whether you've been sent here to make me happy or punish me, it doesn't matter.  The decision we make now is all that matters.  Stay with me.
Person2: Am I really her?
Person1: I don't know anymore.  All I see is you.

Person1: Alright, now tell me. What is it?
Person2: There are opportunities in life for gaining knowledge and experience. Sometimes, in some cases, it's necessary to take a risk. I got to thinking. I'll bet a person could learn a lot by getting into that woman's apartment, you know, sneak in and hide and observe.
Person1: You said it was a strange world. And you're the strangest part of it. Are you crazy? She is possibly involved in murder. This gives me the creeps.
Person2: Settle down. I have a plan which I think will work. There is very little for you to do, but I do need your help. Aren't you curious about my plan?
Person1: It wouldn't hurt to hear the plan, I guess.
Person2: Alright. the first thing is to get into her apartment and open a window that I could crawl into later.
Person1: Now, how are you going to do that?
Person2: Right out in the car I happen to have some old overalls and a bug spraying rig. I will go to her apartment and be the pest control man. I will spray her apartment. After a few minutes you will knock on her door, drawing her attention away from me and I will then jimmy a window.
Person1: What will I say when she comes to the door?
Person2: You will be a Jehovah's Witness. I have a few "Awake" magazines for you. You don't have to keep her very long. A few seconds is all I'll need. Whatiya think?
Person1: I don't know, it sounds like a good daydream, but actually doing it is too weird. Too dangerous.
Person2: Let's just try the first part. If that goes well, we'll see about the rest. No one will suspect us, because no one would believe two people like us would be crazy enough to do something like this.
Person1: You've got a point there.

Person1: It's a miracle she's not dead!

Then, on my personal orders, Regnault proposed 30,000 crowns for her ransom, and once again the answer was no.  And now you say she tried to escape, and the answer is still no.  Jean, open your eyes -- can't you see the hand of God in all this?
Person2: No.  I see the hand of Tremoille, and Regnault, and Yolande, and you... and they are dirty hands.

Person1: When I said you being the best salesman here didn't say much, I meant for us. I know your record with Sarber and Webb, and I'd say you're a top-flight man, but you've had no incentive. No one walking on your heels. Just a lot of half asses, so the tendency's been not to stretch yourself. I'm bouncing the slobs, incidentally.
Person2: So I heard.
Person1: Makes no difference to me if they're only on commission. If they don't make good money, they're not giving us good representation, and we can't afford to have them around. Ever supervise salesmen?
Person2: Just myself.
Person1: That's right, you've had to supervise yourself. This place needs a sales manager. Somebody who's proved he's a salesman and can handle other salesmen. He'd have a lot of deadwood to clear out, new men to hire. What do you think?

Person1: Youre right. I was so desperate to make everyone believe I was happy that I spent six grand on a lie. And after all that? The only one who ended up falling for it was me.
Person2: Go ahead, Kat. Hate me. You were running out of steam on the whole Jeffrey thing. Maybe now youll be able to hold onto this just long enough to ruin your next relationship.

Person1: One question. Do you want to stick to that story, or do you want to keep your teeth?
Person2: I want to keep my teeth.
Person1: Now I'll ask you another. You think I got no contacts out here? That nag paid off at just the opening price. There wasn't hardly a flutter on the tote board from the time the odds were posted. There ain't enough action to tickle the tote, but you claim a ten grand win! You send me ten thousand dollars, like I'm some mark you can blow off!
Person2: Bobo, no, I --
Person1: You wanna talk to me straight up?
Person2: My son --
Person1: Your what?
Person2: My son was in the hospital --
Person1: What are you doing with a son?
Person2: He left home a long time ago. He was in the hospital, up in Los Ang gleez, real sick.
Person1: Motherhood.
Person2: I never messed up before, bobo.
Person1: You expect me to buy this?

Person1: What are you doing?
Person2: I'm moving. Remember? What's with the hooded cloak?
Person1: Nothing. Don't go, Craig. I've been thinking. Let's try to work this out. We've got so much history.
Person2: You should feed your animals. They're looking peaked.
Person1: I'm getting rid of the animals.
Person2: What?
Person1: I'm getting rid of the animals. I've lost interest. Besides, they're standing between you and me.
Person2: No they're not.
Person1: You've always hated the animals.
Person2: You've always loved the animals.
Person1: I'm giving them up. I've changed. I've found a new focus.
Person2: What's that?
Person1: Us, of course.

Person1: There's no point in helping some of them when there are so many others.
Person2: I know perfectly well how little I can do. What I want to do is give passing beggars a roof, some food, and a bit of human warmth.
Person1: Is that all you're going to devote your life to?
Person2: I'm not sure yet. I've had a shock recently, and I'm only beginning to get over it. Perhaps I'll go back to the convent one day.

Person1: Tell them I'm keeping what's left. I earned it.  I probably killed some poor bastard for it.
Person2: He seems to think he's entitled to it all.
Person1: Not all.  They already have a third.  The question is how much of that are they willing to give to get you back?
Person2: You won't shoot me.  That's not your style.
Person1: We might hit a bump and the gun might go off.  Ever see that Tarantino movie -- where Travolta blew that guy away in the back seat -- purely by accident?
Person2: Do you have to point that?
Person1: Absolutely.  And Topanga Canyon has a hell of a lot of potholes if I recall.
Person2: He seems to be headed for Topanga.
Person1: I'm not trying to lose them.  Nor am I exceeding any speed limits.
Person2: The one thing you don't want is to attract the police.
Person1: Granted, the cops are not an alternative.  Certainly not with one of their own still locked in my trunk.
Person2: I don't hear him moving around anymore.
Person1: Those shots your associates got off may not have done him too much good.  That's on their head.  All I did I was put him there.
Person2: A typical mess-up.
Person1: What's that supposed to me?
Person2: I knew you were a loser the first night I laid eyes on you.
Person1: You, I would've noticed.
Person2: Oh no, you were too busy trying to keep some Croatian from slapping the shit out of his girlfriend. She showed her gratitude by almost taking your eye out with her spiked heel.
Person1: You were at the Emerald that night?
Person2: Naturally you didn't learn your lesson.
Person1: I guess I ought to stop seeing woman as victims.
Person2: I think it was my tone of voice more than anything else that sold you.  And when you thought I was being kicked around, I wish I could've seen your face.
Person1: You're enjoying this too much.

Person1: Darling, I just heard.  You poor sausage, are you all right?
Person2: I'm fine.  I got hot.
Person1: Lady H said she thought you might be -
Person2: I'm not pregnant.  I'm hot.  I'm too hot.
Person1: Right.
Person2: Aren't you?
Person1: Sweltering.  Come on, I'll take you home.
Person2: Can't we really go home?  I can't breathe. Aren't you dying for green, anything green, or rain, wouldn't you die to feel rain on your face? It's Christmas and it's all - I don't know - if you asked me I'd go home tomorrow.  If you wanted.
Person1: Sweetheart, you know we can't go home, there might be a war.
Person2: Geoffrey, you do so love putting on a disguise.
Person1: I do so love you.  What do you smell of?
Person2: What?
Person1: Marzipan!  I think you've got marzipan in your hair.  No wonder you're homesick.

Person1: I'm supposed to be leaving on a fellowship that I worked for my entire life.  I don't even care.  I met this boy over the summer, and I, I can't see him because of this, I can't talk to him, I can't talk to my father about... I wore these clothes, I thought, I thought that if I looked right and if I acted right then someone would talk to me.  But I look awful and I feel awful, could you, could you please talk to me?  Be a little decent.
Person2: We believe that your father operates in a large pool of cash that comes from phoney billings, phoney patients.  We've been investigating him for five years.  We believe that when they die, he takes their money.
Person1: Pardon me?
Person2: Look, why don't you check it out for yourself?  See if your father fits the profile.
Person1: What's the profile?
Person2: Well, take a look around the house.  Is everything nice, but not too nice?  Are there lots of, uh, rugs, pieces of art, stereo equipment, uh, furniture, a lot of things bought with cash?  Does he give a lot of gifts?  Do the major items in your house cover around the nine thousand-dollar range?
Person1: You're trying to get me to say something, that's why you're telling me all of this.
Person2: Don't let your father's business infect your life.
Person1: How can you, how can you say that?
Person2: Because he's guilty.
Person1: No, no he's not.
Person2: We have records.  We have proof.  I'm sorry to be the one to have to tell you this, but it's going to get worse.  Now, if I were you, I would take that fellowship.

Person1: What's the matter, Norma?
Person2: Nothing.  I just didn't realize what it would be like to come back to the old studio.  I had no idea how I'd missed it.

Person2: I don't care about the money. I just want to work again.  You don't know what it means to know that you want me.
Person1: Nothing would thrill me more -- if it were possible.
Person2: But remember, darling -- I don't work before ten in the morning, and never after 4

Person1: I'll tell ya what you did, smart boy.  You tied into a loaded mark on 47th across from Maxies.  You and Coleman played the switch for him and blew him off to a cab on 49th.  If he hadn't been a numbers runner for Doyle Lonnegan, it woulda been perfect.

Person1: This is different.  Everybody seems to be in on it.

Person2: That's awful. The poor woman should be taken care of immediately.

Person2: If she was his wife, she should have all the money. That's only fair. I don't want a penny of it.

Person2: I hate and despise you and everything you stand for with all my heart and soul.  I could never forgive what you've done to me and my child.

Person1: Mama, shut up!
Person2: And now you're throwing everything away? You're gonna be a nobody! Nobody! You know what that's like?!
Person1: You... You'd send me back, wouldn't you? You would.

Person1: Yes, but no one is in control of their emotions.  that's all we have time for today...
Person2: I don't understand.

Person2: That's right.
Person1: And you have decided to accept... to accept this "emotion," as you put it, to the ... the "sweepings. of the Lechter case.

Person2: I..

Person2: I want to do something positive...
Person1: You want some advice.
Person2: Yes.

I can't take them, I know they'd just sit around staring at me, and I'd feel embarrassed by them and... they don't fit in with the rest of what's mine, do you understand?  That Sting record you bought for me... that was a present for me.  I like Sting and you hate him.  But the rest of this stuff...  Who the hell is Nick Lowe?  Or Gram Parsons?  Or the Boredoms?  I don't know these people.  I...

Person2: think I left something back at the -

Person1: I've got you, Dr. Evil!
Person2: Well done, Mr. Powers. We're not so different, you and I. It's true, you're British, and I'm Belgian. You have a full head of hair, mine is slightly receding. You're thin, I'm about forty pounds overweight. OK, we are different, I'm not making a very good point. However, isn't it ironic, Mr. Powers, that the very things you stand for-- swinging, free love, parties, distrust of authority- are all now, in the Nineties, considered to be... evil? Maybe we have more in common than you care to admit.
Person1: No, man, what we swingers were rebelling against were uptight squares like you, whose bag was money and world domination. We were innocent, man. If we'd known the consequences of our sexual liberation, we would have done things differently, but the spirit would have remained the same.  It's freedom, man.
Person2: Your freedom has cause more pain and suffering in the world than any plan I ever dreamed of. Face it, freedom failed.
Person1: That's why right now is a very groovy time, man. We still have freedom, but we also have responsibility.
Person2: Really, there's nothing more pathetic than an aging hipster.

Person1: It's just that, you know, I was thinking about how, in class, you're always telling us 'that writers make choices -- at least the good ones. And, don't get me wrong. I'm not saying the book isn't really great -- I mean, really great -- but at times it's, well, very detailed, you know, with the genealogies of everyone's horses and all the dental records and so on -- and I don't know, maybe I'm wrong, but it sort of reads, in places, like, well, actually, like...  ...you didn't make any choices at all. And I was wondering if it might not be different if, maybe, when you wrote, you weren't always... under the influence.
Person2: Uh huh. Well, thanks for the thought, but, as shocking as this may sound, I'm not the first writer to sip a little weed. And furthermore, it might interest you to know that one book I wrote, as you say, 'under the influence,' happened to win a little something called the PEN award which, by the way, I accepted 'under the influence.'

And that's just for the property, mind you.  If you want, I'll leave it to you and your father to dismantle and liquidate the building for whatever salvage value it has, and you keep those proceeds.  I just want the land.

And I said to myself, next time Erin says something nice, does something nice, I'll surprise her with 'em.  Know how long ago that was?  Six months.  In six months, you haven't said one nice thing to me.  That's a long time.

You got document after document here, right under your nose, that says why, and you haven't said word one about it.  I wanna know how the hell you sleep at night.

Person1: Come on, admit it. K worried you, didn't he? He always worried you. In 1942, he's thirty-four years old, you're already fifty-six. And Goebbels and Goering keep saying to you, 'If you don't do it, little K will.' Never mind art and politics and symbols and airy-fairy bullshit about liberty, humanity and justice because I don't care how great you are. It's the oldest story in the book,  The ageing Romeo jealous of the young buck. The real reason you didn't leave the country when you knew you should have was that you were frightened that, once you were out of the way, you'd be supplanted by the Miracle Kid, the Party's boy twice over, flashy, talented little K.
Person2: This is absolute nonsense!
Person1: Well, I'm just beginning to develop my theme. Isn't that what you call it in classical music, developing your theme? Okay, so they played on your insecurity. That's human, understandable. But, there is one guy who doesn't like little K as much as he likes you - yeah, the number one man your old pal, Adolf. He thinks you're the greatest, and when he says, I want Wilhelm for my birthday, boy, they better go out get Wilhelm. So, Josef calls and threatens you with little K. And you said to hell with the Ninth in Vienna, I'll give it to Adolf as a birthday present in Berlin. That's the trick they played, they got you by the balls and they squeezed. Hard. Why did you stay? Why did you play for them? Why were you the flag-carrier for their regime?  Jealousy?
Person2: Of course there was a conspiracy against me, a campaign - even abroad.

Person1: Gillian... Would the whales be at sea by now?

Person1: It's all your fault. Both you little bastards. I was a fool to believe you would bring me any peace. The day your Da left us when you were almost too young to remember, he said the two of you would do me right and make me proud, but he was wrong and I got nothin' ta live for.

Gruel -- it's like Alpo for nuns! I sleep in a cell, on a board, and I pray five times a days  Do you know what I pray for, Eddie, do you have any idea? Person2: Because I am a new man, Susan.  I am a man of vision.  Your problem, Susan, is that you're always looking down.  If you'd just look up you'd see the big picture and in the big picture men of vision do not dwell on what might be lost.  They focus on what can be gained.

Person1: Chopin prelude.  Stodgy, but nice.  Here's the deal.  I didn't want you involved in this.  Still breathing? But now that you are, we have to make the best of it, Max.  Improvise.  Life is that way.  Adapt to your environment.  Survive.  Darwin.  "Shit happens."  The I Ching.  Whatever. Roll with it.

I've come way too far and studied too hard to let my education go to waste as a housewife. And I know that's what I'd become. Sang's already signed with a major firm, and he's going to be pulling a huge salary, which would give me no reason to work, and he's so traditional anyway...

And yes-let me placate your ego-you are the inspiration for this bold and momentous decision, for which I'll probably be ostracized at both school and home. You ask me who I choose, I choose you.

Mr Clark Brandon an almost gentleman of almost complete leisure.  Member of six golf clubs.  Broke 70 once on the Shaughnessy Heights Course.  You have to be good to do that, And if you look out of a front window of the Empress Hotel in Victoria, in a few hours you can look right down on Mr. Brandon's boat, the Valkyrie.  Came alone?  Sure.  He always comes alone.  Mr Brandon's a rather lonely man.

Not if you are young and beautiful. No chance.

What was his name?  "Mommy, we're going out to the ocean -- to go swimming." "But I don't want to go swimming, Norman.  I'm scared." "C'mon, Harry, it'll be fine, it'll be fun."  You heartless fuck.  That's why you're so scared of the water, isn't it?

I'm in this tiny sub on the bottom of the ocean.  All alone.  Surrounded by all this water." Was it really the squid that was attacking you, Norman -- or was it something else -- one of your fears? Person1: Come now, Sam.  This is a gathering of old friends.  I know how difficult this must be for you -- a man of your upbringing and integrity -- but now that I'm in charge I felt it was only fair that you finally know the truth.  After all, you're the only one around here who's still in the dark, as it were.  This isn't the way I wanted to tell you, but you've really given me no other choice.

But having you on the outside has been convenient for us in many ways.  You always did come through -- our loyal watch dog. Finding him. Bringing him back to us once he'd finished his work.  Although after you had that nasty stroke the last time, I had to go after him myself.  And what a terrible time we had getting him out of that jail cell.

Person1: ... He said he had shot his Grandfather with a gun, and then he died in the garden.  And he asked me... he asked me, Tom, if that meant now his father would shoot him out of... revenge.  How does a four year old boy learn the word... 'revenge'?

Person2: You don't know that's true.  But Kay, just for the sake of an argument, let's assume it is, I'm not saying it is, remember, but... What if I gave you what might be some justification for what he did... or rather some possible justification for what he possibly did.

Person2: Okay, just hear me out.  What if Carlo had been paid to help get Sonny killed?  What if his beating of Connie that time was a deliberate plot to get Sonny out into the open? Then what?  And what if the Don, a great man, couldn't bring himself to do what he had to do, avenge his son's death by killing his daughter's husband?  What if that, finally, was too much for him, and he made Michael his successor, knowing that Michael would take that load off his shoulders, would take that guilt?

What's the difference between giving me a bracelet or giving somebody else a hundred thousand dollars for a statue you're going to keep crated up and never look at?  It's only money.  It doesn't mean anything. You're not really giving anything that belongs to you, that you care about.

You're -  - it's like you were bribing me!  That's what it's been from the first moment I met you.  No matter how much it cost you - your time, your money - that's what you've done with everybody you've ever known.  Tried to bribe them!

Person1: You won't find it because no such telegram exists.

Person2: You know something? You should've written our insurance policies for us because you got more exclusion clauses than Double Indemnity. What do you imagine people thought? The Berlin Philharmonic's taken over by Doctor Goebbels and his Propaganda Ministry but Wilhelm is a freelance, so art and politics are now entirely separate? Is that what you believed ordinary people thought?

Person1: No, because I had only one intention. My only intention whatever I did was to show that music means more than politics.
