Person2: Yes, von der Null.
Person1: Von der Null?
Person2: How long's this going to go on, Wilhelm? I say von der Null, you say von der Null, I say von der Null, you say von der Null, we could go on all day. You know who von der Null is, don't you? Edwin von der Nuell, music critic.
Person1: Yes, I know who he is.
Person2: Isn't it true that because he gave you bad reviews and praised this young guy, Von Karajan, called him a goddamn miracle, said he was a better conductor than you, then you had von der Null conscripted into the army and no one's heard from him since?
Person1: That's an outrageous lie!
Person2: You sure you didn't call one of your close buddies and say, God in heaven, did you see what that guy von der Null wrote about me? The greatest conductor on earth. I want him out the way. He had the nerve to accuse me I am not playing enough modern music. Send him to Stalingrad. Isn't that what you did? You don't like criticism, do you, Wilhelm?  You surely didn't like them saying there was another conductor who was better than you... Are you saying the name von der Null was never mentioned in your talks with Goebbels?
Person1: Well. Once he said he'd read what this man wrote about me.
Person2: And what did he say?
Person1: He said, 'Don't mind him. His job is to criticise, your job is to conduct.'

Person1: I have no idea.
Person2: You've really no idea? I'll tell you what happened. He died in Stalingrad.
Person1: I'm sorry.
Person2: Now, that young conductor what's his name?  That miracle kid, you know who I mean. Von Karajan! But you called him something else. C'mon. What did you call von Karajan?

Person2: I want to know exactly who you are and what you're really up to!

Don't go!" And I was just looking at her stupid face and her stupid eyes, stupid mouth and I was filled with disgust, man. And I... Oh, man, I really...

Person1: Same as last time -- the rest after.
Person2: Where do we go?
Person1: When you find the guy, you'll know.
Person2: What shit is this.  I just do it.  I don't prepare it.
Person1: I'll point you in the right direction, but you'll have to take it to the end- zone.  He's a hit-and-run gunman -- I figure he's not cruising the Polo Lounge.
Person2: This is unprofessional.
Person1: See, a successful man like me has limitations -- I lose touch at a street level.  So I have to depend on a smart boy like you who's closer to the nitty and the gritty than I am.
Person2: Disregard you, Mr. whatever-your-name is. This is a lifestyle I embrace.
Person1: That's why I'm letting you take care of this.  I'm the one with appearances to maintain.  But who gives a shit about you?  Not even God.

Person1: You're in one hell of a jam.  You realize that?
Person2: I'm high as a kite.
Person1: Glands.  You're supposed to be happy when you die.  Call me comical again.
Person2: You're a clown.  You're a clown who kills--but you're a clown.
Person1: I love you!  Have a cigar!
Person2: Evolution has made you a clown-- with a cigar.  Simple butchers like you are obsolete!
Person1: I'm to be left behind--in primordial ooze?
Person2: If you're at home in the ooze, and nowhere else.
Person1: This is going to become very physical.  Are you prepared for that?
Person2: You're not such a creature of the ooze that you'd hurt an unarmed man.
Person1: I'm an honorable clown?
Person2: King Arthur.
Person1: You hope.
Person2: In any event, I will not beg for mercy.
Person1: No quarter asked.  No quarter given.
Person2: Don't you laugh even inwardly at the heroic balderdash you spew?
Person1: Cut me open.  Find out.
Person2: I've struck my blow.
Person1: With spittle?
Person2: I've poisoned you. HAROLD  Lucretia Borgia?  Something I drank or touched?  You refused a cigar.  That's it! Potassium cyanide in the humidor! Treacherous lover of peace!
Person2: I put a poisoned thought in your head.  Even now that poison is seeping into every lobe of your mind.  It's saying, "Obsolete, obsolete, obsolete," and, "Clown, clown, clown."
Person1: Poison.
Person2: You have a very good mind, or I wouldn't have come back.  That mind is now asking itself, cleverly and fairly, "Is Harold Ryan really a clown?" And the answer is, "Yes."
Person1: I--I really must congratulate you. Something is happening in there.
Person2: You can never take yourself seriously again!  Look at all the creatures you've protected us from! Did you shoot them on the elevator, as they were on their way up here to eat us alive?
Person1: No. WOODLY The magic root you gave me--I had it analyzed.  It was discovered by a Harvard botanist in 1893!  He explored your famous jungle for five years, armed with nothing but kindness, a talent for languages, and a pocketknife.
Person1: I see.
Person2: You aren't going to hurt me.  You aren't going to hurt anybody any more.  Any violent gesture will seem ridiculous--to yourself!
Person1: Don Quixote.
Person2: My violin is avenged!
Person1: Something seems to have happened to my self-respect.
Person2: And the hell with it.  It was so tragically irrelevant, so preposterously misinformed.
Person1: The new hero is you.
Person2: I hate crowds, and I have no charisma--
Person1: You're too modest.
Person2: But the new hero will be a man of science and of peace--like me. He'll disarm you, of course.  No more guns, no more guns.
Person1: Was I ever of use?
Person2: Never.  For when you began to kill for the fun of it, you became the chief source of agony of mankind.

Person1: And the point is?
Person2: At the exorcism, Birdson boasted that Satan is about to take over the body of a man.  You are that man, Peter.
Person1: What?!?!
Person2: It's true.  Birdson knew your name, he was writing it in numerical code.  It wasn't easy but I figured it out.  It spelled your name.
Person1: Why didn't Birdson just say so?
Person2: If you're possessed, you can't reveal anything Satan wants hidden.  Unless you trick him.
Person1: Trick him.
Person2: The good outwitting the bad.  It's like Birdson had a split personality.
Person1: You should think about getting professional help.
Person2: You're already contaminated.  It's why you couldn't hear the tape.  There's probably a pentacle near your bed.  To sanctify you.
Person1: I'm not going to be drawn into this.
Person2: I know this sounds crazy.  I understand. Check your parents' blood types.  Are you sure your parents are your birth parents?
Person1: My parents are dead.  Don't even think of bringing them into this.

Person1: You wanted to become a member of the most powerful clique in the school. If I wasn't already the head of it, I'd want the same thing.
Person2: I'm sorry? What are you oozing about?
Person1: That episode with the note back there was for all of us to enjoy, but you're determined to ruin my day.
Person2: We made a girl want to consider suicide. What a scream. What a jest.
Person1: Come on you jerk. You know you used to have a sense of humor.

Person1: Forget yesterday's game. The World Series is seven games not six. Put in my bet.
Person2: Let me think about it.
Person1: There's nothing to think about. Either you put in my bet or you ain't getting nothing.

Person2: Yeah.
Person1: I love you.  You know I lo-ove you, I-I love you.  I-I have to invent- Of course I love you.
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: Don't you think I do?
Person2: I dunno.

Person1: Operator...How much would the call be station-to-station?...Thirty-five cents cheaper?...I'd still be short twenty cents ...Just a second, operator...  Colonel, shoot the lock off the Coke machine.  There's bound to be enough change in there.

Person1: Yes?
Person2: What will become of me then?

Person2: I see...
Person1: I'm pleased you're not troubled by the prospect...
Person2: Do as you wish with my body, you'll never possess my soul!

Person2: I don't expect you'd understand.
Person1: My dear Princess, the human soul is a highly elusive commodity.  I suggest you spend some hours before the glass.  Contemplate your intriguing reflection and consider whether such a creature as yourself could possibly possess something as fine and beautiful as a soul.

Person1: That's very nice. Thank you. Thank you for saying that.  You're friends with my sister?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: How long have you known her?
Person2: About six months.
Person1: You like her?
Person2: Yeah. Yeah we get along well.  You didn't get along with her very well?
Person1: Did you really come to meet me on purpose or are you lying about that?
Person2: No, no. I did.
Person1: That's nice. It's nice.  I've been looking around a lot lately at promotional giveaways, cross promotional work by some companies. Do you remember all that pudding?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: So that pudding was bought, I bought that pudding because of a pretty interesting promotion that's sponsored by Healthy Choice and American Airlines. It's designed to encourage airline travel and obviously designed to encourage buying Healthy Choice products. They make frozen meals, deli meats, pasta sauce, breads, soups and ice creams, this sort of thing.....
Person2: Yeah?
Person1: ....I'm sorry....I lost my thoughts, what I was saying....
Person2: You were talking about the promotion --
Person1: -- the promotion says: buy any 10 Healthy Choice products and get 500 miles of airline travel or 1,000 for purchases made with a special coupon. So in the supermarket, you notice their products, first you notice they have a Teriyaki Chicken Dinner at $1.79 - that's a pretty good deal....but then I noticed they had soup at 89 cents a can.....and you start to do the math and you start to notice that it's a really amazing deal because I stumbled across the pudding at 25 cents a cup. Now the crucial thing is the bar codes on the label. That's those little bar codes, you know? The universal product codes?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: That's what's used to redeem the mileage, so in noticing the pudding, each cup had an individual bar code -- in other words, two dollars and fifty cents for ten cups of pudding is 500 miles. Add in the coupon: it's one thousand. You see?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: You see?
Person2: Yeah, no, I see --
Person1: You see if you spent $3,000 dollars on pudding you could earn over one million frequent flyer miles.
Person2: That's insane. That is really, really crazy. That's just crazy if you spend three thousand dollars on pudding.
Person1: ....yeah....
Person2: So that was your pudding?
Person1: ....No....
Person2: I'm sorry. I thought you said --
Person1: No I didn't say that.
Person2: I thought you said you bought all that pudding --
Person1: My friend Carlos is doing it who works with me. It's his. It's his pudding, he's doing it. It's not mine. He's crazy. I told him not to do it. He's the one who's insane. He only spent about one hundred dollars so far though --
Person2: Your sister was telling me a pretty funny story about you, when you guys were kids and you were building a ramp for your dog and you threw a hammer through a window? Is that right? You threw a hammer through a sliding glass door?

Those were the attitudes in the fifties, and that's the way you raised me. But give Nancy a break, encourage her to go to art school.

Person1: What do your instincts tell you to do now, kid?
Person2: Leave. Take this shit back to Detroit and get the rest of our money.
Person1: We could do that. I could be on my way to Florida, and you could go to Thailand and have a great time.
Person2: ...but that's not what we're gonna do, is it?

Person2: It's to follow my instincts. And my instincts say get out of Dodge.
Person1: No, I said to follow 'my' instincts. Now, we go up there and conclude our business. Case closed.

Person1: Okay, I believe you.

Person1: Mrs. Grant, Governor...I won't hurt you.

Person2: That's...a comfort to hear.
Person1: I have a problem.
Person2: Ah.
Person1: Only you can help me. I'm also sorry to say, my problem is your problem, Mrs. Grant.

Person1: Carson was dying so they were forced to leave him. They finally got back to the base, made their report, and waited for the war to end. Only Charles couldn't wait quite as long as the others. He beat them back to the gold, took everything for himself and disappeared. It's taken Gideon, Tex and Scobie all this time to catch up with him again.
Person2: But if they stole all that money -- why can't you arrest them?
Person1: We know what happened from the bits and pieces we were able to paste together -- but we still have no proof.
Person2: But what has all this got to do with the C.I.O.?
Person1: C.I.A., Mrs. Lampert. We're an extension of the wartime O.S.S. It was our money and we want it back.
Person2: I'm sorry, Mr. Bartholomew, but nothing you've told me has changed my mind. I still intend leaving Paris -- tonight.
Person1: I wouldn't advise that, Mrs. Lampert. You'd better consider what happened to your husband when he tried to leave. Those men won't be very far away -- no matter where you go. In fact, I don't even see any point in your changing hotels. Please help us, Mrs. Lampert. Your government is counting on you.
Person2: Well, if I'm going to die, I might as well do it for my country.
Person1: That's the spirit.
Person2: Oh, stop it. What do you want me to do?
Person1: We're anxious to know who this man is -- the one calling himself Dyle.
Person2: Maybe he really is Dyle. He could still be alive.
Person1: No, Mrs. Lampert.
Person2: But no one actually saw him die.
Person1: No, Mrs. Lampert. His death is registered with the War Department in Washington.
Person2: Oh. Then who's this one?
Person1: I don't know -- but I think you'd better find out, don't you?
Person2: Me? Why me?
Person1: You're in an ideal position -- he trusts you.  Besides, you said yourself, women make the best spies.
Person2: Agents.

Person1: Have you ever know a woman? Do you know what it's like to feel her breath on your face... her skin against yours... flesh against flesh?
Person2: My creator did not intend for me to experience these things.
Person1: I'm your creator now.

Person1: Hungry?
Person2: Just some coffee.

Person2: Nothing of the kind. Karen and I had a nice talk.

Person2: I discussed it very openly. I told her that I had spoken to Lloyd - and that he was interested.
Person1: She mentioned, of course, that Margo expects to play the part?
Person2: Oddly enough - she didn't say a word about Margo. Just that she'll be happy to do what she can to see that I play the part.

Person1: Honey, Rose was born on a farm and has terrible memories of farm life. Now I don't think --
Person2: Just a minute, Rose, you don't understand. This isn't a dirt farm like the one you were born on, it's nice. A neighbor of Cousin Hop's, I talked to him on the phone, a fine man... it's not a farm, damn it, it's a beautiful dairy establishment! Stop crying, Rose! Do you hear me? Stop crying, it's ideal!
Person1: I don't know how you can call it ideal -- don't you know what the word "farm" means to her?
Person2: I don't give a hoot in hell's hollow what it means to her! She can't stay in this house forever! I fired her, damn it!

Person2: Trickery and flummery or not, she's going there tomorrow on the bus! It's settled! And I must say we've been more than fair to you, Rose, it's pretty selfish and mean hearted of you to sit there and cry like that!

Person1: You have just made the worst mistake of your lives! You have chosen to join my Army! Person2: Sir, yes, sir!

Person1: It's all kind of lost in the... in the dense mists of time now... It wasn't that I really liked Marco more.  In fact I thought you were more, shall we say, attractive than him.  It was just that he knew he was good-looking and you didn't, and that made a difference somehow.  You used to act as if I was weird for wanting to spend time with you, and that got kind of beat, if you know what I mean.  Your self-image started to rub off on me and I ended up thinking that I was strange.  And I knew that you were kind and thoughtful... you made me laugh, and I dug the way you got consumed by things you loved... and Marco seemed a bit more, I don't know, glamorous? More sure of himself?  Less hard work, because I felt like I was dragging you around, sort of.  A little sunnier.  Sparkier.  I don't know.  You know what people are like at that age.  They make very superficial judgements.  Do you think that's superficial?  He was a clown, if it's any consolation.

But can I tell you something else, it'd be nice to see the big guy without you next to him.  What are you, his shadow?  Do you assist him with everything, even the simplest tasks?  You know some- times somebody would like a few min- utes alone with W.P.  That means without you.  Okay, pal?  Let's eat.

Person1: I understand how you feel, Cookie. It's sort of rough -- one American squealing on other Americans. Then again, Cookie -- maybe that stoolie's not an American at all. Maybe he's a German the Krauts planted in this barracks. They do this type of thing. Just put an agent in with us -- a trained specialist. Lots of loose information floating around a prison camp. Not just whether somebody wants to escape, but what outfits we were with and where we were stationed, and how our radar operates. Could be, couldn't it?
Person2: In this barracks?
Person1: Why not? Just one of the boys. Sharing our bunks. Eating our chow. Right in amongst the ones that beat me up. Except that he beat hardest.
Person2: Who is it?
Person1: That's not the point, Cookie. The point is what do you do with him? You tip your mitt and the Jerries pull him out of here and plant him someplace else, like Stalag Sixteen or Fifteen. Or you kill him off and the Krauts turn around and kill off the whole barracks. Every one of us. So what do you do?
Person2: Who is it?

Person2: Jerry-boy - why do you have to paint everything so black? Suppose you get hit by a truck? Suppose the stock market crashes?

I don't have a right to ask this, and you can kick me out of your house if you want, but this is my profession and there's a part of me that can't let it go.  Police are just as human as you or I.  They could have missed something.  They probably didn't.  Wouldn't you rather know?

I'm gonna win my way into the lives and hearts of people even if I have to kill to do it.  I'll make the pathetic little crumbs love me. I don't even know why I'm wasting my time here with you.  I should be with my people...

Person2: Actually, I already work for you. Or did.  Your arboreal preservation project in South America.

Person2: I see you knew him.

Person2: You know, everything you asked me to do I did. I call you for advice about Shari you say -  "Leave her be, see other people for a while." You just wanted me to get involved with Jill because it made for a better show.

Person2: No. You screwed up my life just so you could get higher ratings. You never gave a shit about me.

Person1: What do you mean you and my father decided? Who the hell are you to plan my life? Let's get married and live happily ever after. Bullshit. I got knocked up. I had to marry you. I never had a choice.
Person2: What?
Person1: You betrayed me, Charlie. You were never there for me or the children. And now you come and tell me, "Peggy, you're scared." Of course I'm scared. If you knew what I knew you'd be scared shitless.
Person2: You're crazy! You're really out of your mind!
Person1: I might be crazy, but I'm not crazy enough to marry you twice. There's a lot of things I can't change. I can't even think about them. I tried. But I couldn't even help Rosalie.  I don't want to be bitter. I'm a naturally optimistic person. But you took advantage of that.

Person1: Wait, wait...
Person2: For what?
Person1: Because... because -- I mean -- the English have a broad sense of humor, but... I mean, you don't understand... to them you're a witch, working for the devil.  What makes you think they'll listen to you?
Person2: Because if they don't, I'll raise such a war-cry against them that they will remember us forever!
Person1: Well.  I'd love to see that, but after taking counsel with my captains, I felt it would be better to first bring the food into the city, then wait till Alencon arrives with reinforcements before doing anything.
Person2: You may have been with your counsel, but I've been with mine, and I'm telling you, God's counsel is wiser than yours, and he's telling me to speak to the English -- now!
Person1: Fine -- go now if you want, but not with me!  You may have a duty to God but I have a duty to my people, and my people are starving!  So right now I'm going to take the food back to the city, and if you can please calm down, and let me accompany you to Orleans, it will be my honor to welcome you.

Person1: Do you mind if I smoke, Mr. Garrison?
Person2: How could I?  Dave, as you know, President Kennedy was assassinated on Friday.  A man named Lee Harvey Oswald was arrested as a suspect and then was murdered yesterday by a man named Jack Ruby.  We've heard reports that Oswald spent the summer in New Orleans and we've been advised you knew Oswald pretty well.
Person1: That's not true.  I never met anybody named Oswald.  Anybody who told you that has to be crazy.
Person2: But you are aware, he served in your Civil Air Patrol unit when he was a teenager.
Person1: No... if he did, I don't remember him.  There were lots of kids in and out... y'know.
Person2: I'm sure you've seen this.  Perhaps you knew this man under another name?
Person1: No, I never saw him before in my life.
Person2: Well that must've been mistaken information we got.  Thanks for straightening it out for us.  There is one other matter that's come up, Dave.  We were told you took a trip to Texas shortly after the assassination of Friday.
Person1: Yeah, now that's true.  I drove to Houston.
Person2: What was so appealing about Houston?
Person1: I hadn't been there ice skating in many years, and I had a couple of young friends with me, and we decided we wanted to go ice skating.
Person2: Dave, may I ask why the urge to go ice skating in Texas happened to strike you during one of the most violent thunderstorms in recent memory?
Person1: Oh, it was just a spur of the moment thing...  the storm wasn't that bad.
Person2: I see.  And where did you drive?
Person1: We went straight to Houston, and then Saturday night we drove to Galveston and stayed over there.
Person2: Why Galveston?
Person1: No particular reason.  Just to go somewhere.
Person2: And then Sunday?
Person1: In the morning we went goose hunting. Then headed home, but I dropped the boys off to see some relatives and I stayed in Hammond.
Person2: Did you bag any geese on this trip?
Person1: I believe the boys got a couple.
Person2: But the boys told us they didn't get any.
Person1: Oh yes, well, come to think of it, they're right.  We got to where the geese were and there were thousands of them.  But you couldn't approach them.  They were a wise bunch of birds.
Person2: Your young friends also told us you had no weapons in the car.  Dave, isn't it a bit difficult to hunt for geese without a shotgun?
Person1: Yes, now I remember, Mr. Garrison. I'm sorry, I got confused.  We got out there near the geese and it was only then we realized we'd forgotten our shotguns.  Stupid, right?  So of course we didn't get any geese.
Person2: I see.  Dave thank you for your time.  I'm sorry it has to end inconveniently for you, but I'm going to have you detained for further questioning by the FBI.
Person1: Why?  What's wrong?
Person2: Dave, I find your story simply not believable.

Person1: That's him. Let him in.
Person2: Wait a minute--Jim--you didn't ask Smith over here!
Person1: What do you think?
Person2: Jim, you can't come here and pull that steamroller stuff. Your methods won't do here. This boy is a Senator, however it happened, he's a Senator. This is Washington.
Person1: Steamroller stuff, Joe? My methods don't go in Washington? They've done pretty well by now, haven't they?
Person2: Oh, Jim, that's beside the point. This boy's different. He's honest and beside he thinks the world of me. We can't do this to him.
Person1: Well, what do you want me to do? Stand around like you chump and let that drooling infant wrap that Willet Creek Dam appropriation around my neck. Either he falls in line with us and behaves himself or I'll break him so wide open they'll never be able to find the pieces.
Person2: Jim, I won't stand for it.
Person1: You won't stand for it?
Person2: I don't want any part of crucifying this boy.
Person1: Oh, I see. Out steamroller methods are getting too hard to your sensitive soul, is that it, Joe? The Silver Knight is getting to big for us. My methods have been all right for the past twenty years, Joe, since I picked you out of a fly-specked hole in the wall and blew you up to look like a Senator, and now you can't stand it. Well, maybe you won't have to stand it, Joe. Maybe we can fix it so you and your Boy Ranger can go home together.
Person2: Jim, you don't have to--
Person1: Oh, it's all right--it's all right. It seems a shame, though, to part company like this after all these years, especially now with a national convention coming up. Joe, I've put everything I have behind you. And so did all of our friends, but I guess we'll survive. We'll just have to find somebody else that's got a little more sense, that's all. In the meantime, you explain to Mr. Smith about Willet Dam. It's your bill-- it's your reputation, and if he can't find enough facts to break you with, you just send him to me and I'll give him a couple of good ones. I'm taking the next plane home.
Person2: Jim, it's just that I like the kid-- I don't want to see you get too rough on him.
Person1: I'm glad to see you come to your senses. You had me scared there for a minute, thought.  Let him in.

Person1: C'mon, I need to talk to you. Just the two of us.

Person1: Apart from that, you look pretty chipper for a man who's two thousand and thirty one years old.  I read the clocks. They bear out Hasslein's hypothesis. We've been away from Earth for two thousand years, give or take a decade.  Still can't accept it, huh?
Person2: long pause) You know it.

Person2: Prove it. If we can't get back, it's still just a theory.

Person1: He remind you of that guy, Tillman?
Person2: Not at all.
Person1: But you know he's dirty and you still wanna see him again.
Person2: I want to bust his ass, put him in shackles.
Person1: Maybe.  But you're also curious about the man.  Twice last night you asked your married boyfriend Nicolet about him.  You were concerned, but you didn't want to show it.
Person2: My married boyfriend - setting him up with that news story so you could talk about infidelity.  I couldn't believe it.
Person1: You like the wild ones, don't you? Tillman, Nicolet and now Foley.  You know, I've always said there's a thin line between the cowboy cops and the armed robbers, all those guys that love to pack.
Person2: Foley kidnapped me.
Person1: Yeah, but you talked all the way from GCI to the turnpike.  It sounds more like a first date than a kidnapping.

Person1: As for you, my galvanized friend, you want a heart! You don't know how lucky you are not to have one. Hearts will never be practical until they can be made unbreakable. I could have been a world figure, a power among men, a - a successful wizard, had I not been obstructed by a heart.
Person2: But I still want one.
Person1: Yes -- ....

Person1: She has no idea who I am.
Person2: Why are you following me?
Person1: I'm trying to help you. I knew she'd get her claws into you. She doesn't know anything about your investigation, so when she offers to help you, it'll be for her own reasons. Why would I lie? Do not go back to her. Take out a pen, write yourself a note, do not trust her.

Person1: You take all my money, but you're borrowing part of it?
Person2: At eighteen percent, okay? And don't ask me no more questions. I'm leaving.

Person1: Do you always drive like this?
Person2: Yes.

Person1: Right, partner.
Person2: Get this. We ain't partners. We ain't brothers. We ain't friends. If Ganz gets away with my money, you're gonna be sorry we ever met.
Person1: Yeah.  Right.

Person1: I'm sorry, darlin', I hate it as much as you do.
Person2: Well, she does seem to cause a lot of trouble, I admit. But she doesn't mean any harm and it'll break the children's hearts, they all love her.
Person1: It's because of the children she's got to go. I don't want to be holier-than-thou, but the girl doesn't have the same outlook we do. Morals don't mean a thing to her, not a thing, and we can't have a girl like that in this house.
Person2: Who is to say our morals are better than hers?  But maybe you're right. She could... influence Dolly...
Person1: That is exactly what I'm afraid of.  The girl has got to go, darlin'.
Person2: But morals come from the heart, not from rigid rules and empty laws. And in her heart Rose has never hurt anyone and she never would. Therefore, she's not immoral. Not really.
Person1: Now look, darlin', this is no time to go off into the fourth dimension.
Person2: But what I said is the simple truth. And now I see something else, I see more deeply into it...

Person1: Why, you don't want us to bring him over?
Person2: No, it's that when do you have time to be parents to him? You guys don't pick him up until nine, ten at night. You are into yourselves, as the saying goes. Spend some time trying to be parents. Take him to the mountains, fishing. You ought to let him get to know nature.
Person1: Well, you are his grandfather. He is supposed to spend some time with you. You're supposed to show him those woodsy things and this and that.
Person2: Junior spends time with his child.
Person1: Oh here we go with that.

Person1: Nobody wants any more killings; we all agree to that, correct?  That's good.  Now, Eric, you're gonna hand your prisoner over to us.
Person2: Screw you.
Person1: This isn't your concern.  It's over, here and now.

Person1: ...Just a second here, I'll give you a receipt on the, uh... Whoa, Nellie... Oh, by the way, we didn't talk about this, I, uh, I think I'm gonna call the place Tolliver's, after me, you know, I didn't think you were much interested in, uh--
Person2: That'll be fine.
Person1: Yeah, good. Lemme just, uh...

Person1: You think he got the point?
Person2: What're you doin'? He's a square guy, for chrissakes.  You can't treat him like that. He's gonna run to the FBI.
Person1: Fuck the FBI! That prick's been dodging me for three weeks. And what is it with you?  All of a sudden, you're tryin' to tell me what to do all the time.
Person2: I'm not tryin' to tell you what to do. But you were way out of line, Nick. What're you doin'? Where's your head?
Person1: Where's my head? Where's your balls? Huh? You know I'm tryin' to put somethin' really big together out here. You know what I'm talkin' about, huh? You know!  If you're actin' like this now, how can I depend on you?  There's a lot of things gonna change out here. And if you wanna be there with me, Sammy, you're gonna have to go my way.
Person2: Listen, Nick, you gotta understand my situation. I'm responsible for thousands of people. I got a hundred million a year goin' through the place.  It's all over, I'm gonna tell you, it's all over, if I don't get that license.  And believe me, if it goes bad for me, it's gonna go bad for a lot of people, you understand?
Person1: Yeah, forget about your license. I plant my own flag out here, you ain't gonna need a license.  You know, I don't know what it is, Sammy, but the more I talk to you, the more I feel like you just don't wanna go along with me, is that it?
Person2: No, I don't wanna come -
Person1: You should say so.
Person2: I don't wanna come along with you.
Person1: Just say so.
Person2: I'll be honest with you.
Person1: All right, fine.
Person2: I don't wanna be involved in anything you're talkin' about...
Person1: Fine.

Person1: "Let all who love me follow me"... Where does God get mentioned?  Come on Jeanne, be honest.  You fought for yourself, in your name.
Person2: I... I was defending myself as best I could!  Everyone has the right to defend themselves, don't they?  Or should I have let myself be killed?
Person1: No, no, you did fine.  I'd even say well done.  Besides, most of the ones you killed probably deserved it, don't you think?
Person2: No, I do not think so.  I don't think that killing each other will ever bring peace.
Person1: I agree...

Person1: What's a matter with you? Are you crazy?
Person2: Why the heck, outta all the god forsaken places in Mexico, did you have us rendezvous at that place?
Person1: I don't know, one place's as good as another.
Person2: Have you ever been there before?
Person1: No, but I passed by it a couple of times. It's out in the middle of nowhere. It seems like a rowdy place, so there wouldn't be a lot of police. And it's open from dusk till dawn. You said meet you in the morning.
Person2: Well, because you picked that place out of a hat, my brother's dead now. And this girl's family's dead.

Person1: Why not?
Person2: Oh come on, Kathryn. It's too easy. "But I thought high school was only four years." I mean, please. She knows nothing. She's seen nothing. I could have her under the table at Au Bar sucking me off before the appetizer arrived. Go get one of those moron friends of yours to do it. I have a reputation to uphold.
Person1: Oh but diddling the therapist's daughter is a challenge?
Person2: That was just simple revenge. What I have planned requires sheer genius.

Person1: Come on. We're goin' over to Elton's.
Person2: I'm not.
Person1: You just going to sit there?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: Okay. Hope no one hits on you.
Person2: I hope they do.

Person1: Why did you leave the dishes in the sink again? I thought we agreed to clean up after ourselves.
Person2: Oh, so now you're tracking every little thing I do?
Person1: I just want some help around here.
Person2: I see you want to start a fight. Maybe we should discuss this when we're both calm.

Person1: How could you do this to me?
Person2: I'm in love with you.
Person1: Oh, come on...  What kind of an excuse is that?

Person1: Shit, John!  What the hell were you doing out there?!
Person2: Nothing.
Person1: You're kidding with that answer, right?
Person2: I just went for a walk.  It's no big deal.
Person1: Wrong.  There are rules in this house and you're going to follow them whether you like it or not.
Person2: Or what?  You're gonna shoot me?
Person1: It's an option.
Person2: Well, maybe if you'd let me live in the dorms, I wouldn't have to sneak out to spend time with my friends.
Person1: Oh, so now it's my fault?
Person2: Just forget it...

Person1: Don't make me come there. Answer me.
Person2: I love you.

Person1: Sandro, I don't want you to come with me, I don't want to see you... How can I make it clear to you?...Why did you come?
Person2: I don't know why. I just couldn't help it.
Person1: But sooner or later we've got to end this relationship. And it's better to do it right now.
Person2: I have no desire to sacrifice myself... It's idiotic to sacrifice oneself... Why?... For whom? If Anna were here I might understand your scruples. But she's not...
Person1: Oh, Sandro...
Person2: I'm sorry. I didn't want to sound cynical. But isn't it better to look things squarely in the eye?
Person1: For me they are exactly as they were when we met three days ago -- just three days ago... don't you realize? And you and Anna... No, I guess they aren't like that any more. My God, is it possible to forget in such a short time, for things to change so quickly?
Person2: It takes even less.
Person1: But it's so sad. So terribly sad. I'm not used to it, I'm not ready for it... You know... I have never been so upset in my life. Sandro, why don't you help me?
Person2: I think the only way to help ourselves, Claudia, is for us to be together.
Person1: No, I'm sure it won't. Move over there. Let's make believe nothing happened. And when we get to the next station, get off.
Person2: And what about you?
Person1: Me... I... I... Please leave me alone.

Person1: I don't want her to go, Lillian.
Person2: Don't cause a scene. No one's trying to win any 'rounds'. Don't make it any worse.
Person1: I'm not making it any worse. You are. Me and Jill could've worked this thing out. It's normal, it's even normal for me to get a little touchy about it. Believe it or not. How do you think this makes me look, treating her like some tragic victim or something?

Person1: We gotta face some facts here.
Person2: What facts are those?
Person1: I understand how it could happen.  I know why any guy would love her.  And I can't blame you that it happened.  You thought I was dead, she was grieving, you were trying to help her.
Person2: I was grieving too.
Person1: Yeah, right.  Anyway, you didn't know.
Person2: So what are you saying?
Person1: I'm saying now you do know.  So it's time for you to move on.
Person2: You left her.  How's that for a fact?
Person1: How's this for a fact?  I loved her first.

Person1: I can get you a job.
Person2: A job?
Person1: Yes, the money is good.
Person2: As a plumber?!
Person1: It's easy to learn.
Person2: A job??  As a plumber???  You think I come to America to work!
Person1: We started over, you can too.
Person2: You spent all the money while I was in prison?  Now you tell me to get a job fixing toilets?!?

Person1: When aid you get home last night...?
Person2: What were you talking about...?
Person1: Yyou look terrible.  You're exhausted. You practically live at the goddamn clinic.    Even pregnant women who aren't doctors know that You can't -

Person1: We may have a chance.
Person2: Yes... a very slim one. I want to be fair. I don't deny that you might make out some kind of a case.
Person1: We haven't anything to discuss with you. We'll talk to a lawyer!
Person2: All right -- go ahead... you talk to the lawyer and I'll talk to the judge!

Person1: What do you mean?
Person2: Well, I assume you let him kiss you?
Person1: Well yeah. Of course. Everyone kisses.
Person2: I'm not criticizing. _ Did you two get any further?
Person1: A little.
Person2: How much further?
Person1: Daddy! I DON'T THINK THIS IS ANY OF YOUR BUSINESS!
Person2: I wouldn't ask if I didn't have to.
Person1: Not much further.
Person2: You never went, uh, all the way?

Person1: You're unnerved because you've spent your whole life thinking nobody is looking over you, and suddenly your subconscious is an open book.  We are, for the first time, experiencing changes in natural reality by a force not our own.  That proves that --
Person2: -- we are not sure of that.  We are not sure we aren't all hallucinating.
Person1: If God is beyond our comprehension, and she --  -- is here for reasons that can't be understood, isn't God here?
Person2: Not necessarily.
Person1: Stop equivocating!  Unbelievable, how you equivocate!  You, the atheist, you're more dogmatic than any holy person I've ever seen!  This is happening, Kelvin.  Wake up.
Person2: Consciousness is enough, that's all I've saying.  Consciousness should be enough for anybody.
Person1: Who are you trying to convince?

Person1: Not with your own cloth. Besides, your pockets will be stitched.
Person2: What happens if I want to sneeze?
Person1: You won't. Not without permission.

Person1: I hear what you're saying, but I know what you're thinking.
Person2: What?
Person1: You're thinking exactly what I thought when I first saw this house,
Person2: What's that?
Person1: This -- is -- the -- one -- for -- us.
Person2: Stop knowing me so well.
Person1: I know it's at the high end of our range --
Person2: High end?  Honey, it's a whole new budget.
Person1: But it's what we want.
Person2: You wanted furniture too, didn't you?
Person1: They don't expect to get what they're asking.  Let's make an offer.
Person2: You want me to bargain at the high end of our range?  -- I'll have a stroke.  I've got to save all my sweat for my meeting in three weeks.
Person1: You could have a pool to cool off in.
Person2: It's a nice pool, isn't it?
Person1: And it's a shorter commute.
Person2: It'll be even shorter if I get that new job.  Come on.

Person1: Hey! Wait a minute! There's no birthday party for me here!
Person2: Thank you, Desmond.  What's the reason for your truancy?
Person1: I couldn't make it in time.
Person2: You mean, you couldn't? Or you wouldn't?
Person1: I don't know, mon. The food lines took forever.
Person2: Food will be eaten on your time!  Why are you continuously late for this class, Mr. Spicoli? Why do you shamelessly waste my time like this?
Person1: I don't know.

Person1: I am worrying.  Seems to me, you're starting to get confused as to which side of the line you're standing on.
Person2: Pretty hollow words coming from a man who spent the last year running with the enemy.
Person1: What the hell is that supposed to mean?
Person2: It means I'm starting to wonder if the vampires still have their hooks in you. You've been acting strange ever since I gave you the cure.  Reckless, quick to anger --  You said it yourself, Whistler.  Those vampires knew our defense system backwards and forwards.  Where'd they get their intel?

Person1: I wish you could see the world as I do. Deacon opened my eyes. There's no turning back from that.
Person2: I don't believe that.
Person1: You will. Time is on our side. Sooner or later, the Thirst always wins.

Person1: I've hired you to help me start a war. That's a prestigious line of work with a long and glorious tradition.
Person2: I just don't think it's right, killing an innocent girl.
Person1: Am I going mad or did the word "think" escape your lips? You were not hired for your brains, you hippopotamic land mass.

Person1: Commander, I have to log it...
Person2: That's a direct order. You didn't see a thing!

Person1: It's like nothing I've ever felt before. I think I'm going crazy.
Person2: I'm sure you're not going crazy.
Person1: Kevin, I'm telling you... it was like nothing I've...
Person2: Yeah yeah yeah. Yadda yadda yadda. Were you stoned?
Person1: Yes, but you see, someone else was talking through my mouth.
Person2: You were stoned. Case closed. End of story. How hot is this babe?
Person1: I think it might've been this Lotte woman talking through me. Maxine likes to call me Lotte.
Person2: Ouch. Now that's hot. She's using you to channel some dead lesbian lover. Let me know when you're done with her. This is my type of chick.
Person1: I'm done with her now. Tonight really creeped me out.
Person2: You're crazy to let go of a chick who calls you Lotte. I tell you that as a friend.
Person1: I don't know anything about her. What if she's some sort of witch or something?
Person2: All the better. Hey, Hot Lesbian Witches, next Geraldo, buddy boy. Ha ha ha.
Person1: I gotta know the truth, Kevin.
Person2: The truth is for suckers, Johnny-Boy.

Person1: Look, we gotta think about everyone now -- the kid especially. How scared is she gonna be out there?
Person2: Oh, don't use her like that, for a smoke screen.
Person1: Smoke screen for what?
Person2: For your own fear.
Person1: Hey. Why don't you rag your hole for two seconds and let someone else come up with a plan that doesn't involve MASS SUICIDE?

Person1: Why did they do all this for goodness sake?--what were they after?
Person2: Total manipulation. I suppose you could say they wanted to subvert the Constitution, but they don't think along philosophical lines.
Person1: Talk about Segretti--
Person2: --don't concentrate on Segretti or you'll miss the overall scheme too.
Person1: There were more then.
Person2: Follow every lead--every lead goes somewhere--
Person1: --the Canuck letter--was that a White House operation--
Person2: --don't you miss the grand scheme too.
Person1: How grand?
Person2: Nationwide--my God, they were frightened of Muskie and look who got destroyed--they wanted to run against McGovern, and look who they're running against. They bugged, they followed people, false press leaks, fake letters, they canceled Democratic campaign rallies, they investigated Democratic private lives, they planted spies, stole documents, on and on-- don't tell me you think this was all the work of little Don Segretti.
Person1: And Justice and FBI know all this?
Person2: Yes, yes, everything. There were over fifty people employed by the White House and CREEP to ratfuck-- some of what they did is beyond belief.
Person1: Fifty ratfuckers directed by the White House to destroy the Democrats?
Person2: I was being cautious.  You can safely say more then fifty...

Person1: Damn, Max.  I'm impressed.  Really.  I would have bet good money you wouldn't walk out of there.
Person2: Makes two of us.

Person1: It's you, David.
Person2: What?!
Person1: You survived and now you shall continue the curse.
Person2: What are you talking about? I won't accept this! Get out! God damit!
Person1: Remember what that guy at The Slaughtered Lamb said? 'Beware the moon.'
Person2: Stop it, Jack.
Person1: Beware the moon. The full moon, David. You've got two days.
Person2: Jack, please go away. Please go away.
Person1: You'll stalk the streets of London a creature of the night.
Person2: You're talking like Boris Karloff! It's movie dialogue!
Person1: David, please believe me. You will kill people, David. You've got to stop the bloodshed before it begins.
Person2: Nurse!
Person1: Listen to me! Take your own life, David. It's our only chance.
Person2: Nurse!
Person1: The supernatural! The powers of darkness! It's all true. Take your own life! Suicide, David. Join me.
Person2: Nurse! Oh God! Alex!
Person1: It's cold, David, and I'm so alone. The undead surround me. Have you ever talked to a corpse? It's boring! I'm lonely! Kill yourself, David, before you kill others.

Person1: Mr. Caiman, you're married.
Person2: And you're beautiful...
Person1: Mr. Caiman...
Person2: Call me Charlie.
Person1: Mr. Caiman, I've been doing extra research for you after hours and weekends for nearly a year. And I've never asked for anything but this job is really important to me. I'm too old to be an assistant anymore. I need to know this job is going someplace.
Person2: So have dinner with me tonight.
Person1: I can't.
Person2: It's your choice.

Person1: I still believe that we should pursue the organic marketing route. It's more sustainable in the long run.
Person2: But paid advertising has immediate results. We can't wait months to see a return on our efforts.
Person1: If you understood what I was saying, youâ€™d agree with me. Organic growth builds trust and loyalty among our customers.
Person2: I get your point, but we need short-term results as well. Maybe we can find a middle ground?
Person1: That sounds reasonable. Let's strike a balance.

Person1: So.  I'm assuming they sent you here to administer last rites?
Person2: I'm not sure it's come to that.
Person1: They don't believe me.
Person2: I do.
Person1: You're sure you want to?  In the universe I saw we're not exactly the stars of the show.  What happened to me makes us all seem pretty damn small.
Person2: It also makes God enormous.  I think of the scope of your universe, Ellie... and it takes my breath away.  As it will everyone else's.
Person1: I don't have any proof, Palmer.
Person2: Ellie, you're the proof.  You tell them your story.  Ultimately they'll have no choice but to believe you.
Person1: It's not enough, don't you understand?  I know it happened -- but by every standard of science, by every standard I've lived my life by that fact is utterly beside the point.  It may be true but it doesn't matter because I can't prove it's real.
Person2: Ellie, the only one holding you to that standard is you!  The people want to hear your story, they need to hear it!
Person1: But --
Person2: Have you seen what's happening out there?  The terror, the despair? The world is on fire, Ellie.  People need something they can believe in, something worthy, and you can give it to them!
Person1: I want to, Palmer -- more than anything.  But it has to be real. It has to be true.
Person2: Ellie... if you go out there like this -- if you admit to even the possibility that what you experienced didn't actually happen -- I'm afraid they really will crucify you.  Please.  For your own sake, for the sake of the world... tell them what you know to be the truth.  Tell them it really happened.

Person1: No more witnesses. West's a ghost. But it doesn't matter because we have your signature, the hospital log, and Kendall's toxicology report. And that'll be enough.
Person2: You're crazy --
Person1: You can't duck this, Bill. I may have done every goddamn thing in my life wrong but I won't let this happen.
Person2: For the last time, I have no idea what you're talking about --
Person1: Get your hands away from the desk!

Person1: Oh, you know, I, I love that book you lent me.  The Easter Parade? You were right.  It had very special meaning for me.
Person2: How's Frederick?  He didn't come.

Person1: Listen ... why don't you come out to the house this weekend.  Say hello to the kids. They've grown.
Person2: I hate your kids, Frank.
Person1: You're their uncle.
Person2: Only by relation.  Besides, they hate me, too.
Person1: They don't.  They're always asking about you.
Person2: They tried to electrocute me, Frank.
Person1: It was an accident.
Person2: It was no accident, Frank. The little one ...
Person1: Cindy.
Person2: She threw a goddamn radio into the bathtub. How do you explain that?
Person1: She didn't know what she was doing. You're too sensitive.
Person2: You got weird kids, Frank.
Person1: Look, I just thought if you came out you might see what you're missing.

Person1: He rides tonight.
Person2: Father saw you die.
Person1: He saw me thrown... saw the Horseman looming over me as I fled.  Things I wanted him to see.  But, as long as I govern the Horseman, he cannot harm me.  Baltus did not stay enough to see that.  He ran as a coward, unfettered by my fate.

Person1: Paid the Alamo ten bucks to put the shiv in me. He's a lifer, what does he care. Paid a hospital guard fifty to put out the story I was dead. Once the wound healed up...  Got out of the Mountain this morning. And tonight I'm a rich man.
Person2: How'd you know I'd do it.
Person1: Do what?
Person2: Walk outta there and tell her I was you.

Person1: Do not lecture me about treaty violations. The Federation, in creating an ultimate weapon, has become a gang of Intergalactic criminals. It is not I who will surrender, it is you.  On the planet below, I have three prisoners from the team who developed your doomsday weapon. If you do not surrender immediately, I will execute them, one at a time, as enemies of galactic peace.
Person2: Who is this?! How dare you --
Person1: Who I am is not important. That I have them is.  I will let you speak to them.

Person1: You don't think I'll do it, do you?
Person2: I think you're crazy!
Person1: Where is it?
Person2: Where's what?
Person1: The money!
Person2: Caesar, I don't know what you're thinking here, but if you don't put down that gun --

Person1: I'm impressed. I didn't think you could do it. What did you have to do, steal them?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: That's not going to look too good on your service record.
Person2: I'll worry about that. Let's get on with it.

Person1: No matter how I keep turning it around in my mind -- it doesn't seem like the right thing.
Person2: For who?
Person1: For anyone. They'll never be able to live through the talk. Richard will never be able to. He doesn't deserve that. He hasn't hurt anyone in his life.
Person2: Then he can move! People move!
Person1: His family's lived for almost a hundred years. Richard doesn't know how to live anywhere else. And the kids...
Person2: The kids are grown! They don't need you anymore. You told me that. They hardly talk to you.
Person1: No, they don't say much. But Carolyn's 16. She's just about to find out about all this for herself -- she's going to fall in love, she's going to try and figure out how to build a life with someone. If I leave what does that say to her?
Person2: What about us? What about me?
Person1: You've got to know deep down that the minute we leave here. It'll all change.
Person2: Yeah. It could get better.
Person1: No matter how much distance we put between us and this house, I bring with it with me. And I'll feel it every minute we're together. And I'll blame loving you for how much it hurts. And then even these four days won't be anything more than something sordid and... a mistake.
Person2: Francesca, listen to me. You think what's happened to us happens to just anybody? What we feel for each other? How much we feel? We're not even two separate people anymore. Some people search their whole lives for it and wind up alone -- most people don't even think it exists and you're going to tell me that giving it up is the right thing to do? That staying here alone in a marriage, alone in a town you hate, in a house you don't feel apart of anymore -- you're telling me that's the right thing to do!?
Person1: We are the choices we've made, Robert.
Person2: TO HELL WITH YOU!

Person1: You are?
Person2: Yes, I am.
Person1: What are you trying to tell me?
Person2: What Roma's trying to tell you. What I told you yesterday.  Why you don't belong in this business.
Person1: Why I don't...
Person2: You listen to me, someday you might say, "Hey..." No, forget that, you just listen what I'm going to say: your partner depends on you.  Your partner...a man who's your "partner" depends on you...you have to go with him and for him...or you're shit, you're shit, you can't exist alone...
Person1: Excuse me...
Person2: ...excuse me, nothing, you be as cold as you want, but you just messed up a good man out of six thousand dollars and his goddamn bonus 'cause you didn't know the shot, if you can do that and you aren't man enough that it gets you, then I don't know what, if you can't take some thing from that...  you're scum, you're fucking white-bread.  You be as cold as you want. A child would know it, he's right.  You're going to make something up, be sure it will help or keep your mouth closed.

Person1: Look, I can understand if you and Foley are close.
Person2: We're not.  I'm helping him, yeah--
Person1: Wait.  Have you helped him, Glenn?  At this point, technically, I doubt you could be charged with aiding a fugitive. So you still have a choice.  You can help him and risk going down again, get cuffed and shackled, hope to God you pull a reasonable judge, not some hard-on.  Or, if you want to play it another way...

Person1: Carol and I saw you with that creep, Richard, today.
Person2: First of all, Richard is not a creep. He happens to be an exceptional person. If any of you gave him half a chance, you'd find that out.
Person1: God, Peggy, you're so unformed you're practically fetal. You're just taking pity on him 'cause he has no friends.
Person2: Dolores, can't you be a little kinder to people? You don't even know the boy. If you weren't so neurotic and insecure, maybe you'd shut up for a while and show some compassion.
Person1: Are you for real?
Person2: Touchy, touchy!

Person1: It's just money.  You should be glad you're alive.
Person2: It might be best if we didn't talk.
Person1: All I mean is... someone like you...
Person2: How many times have you done this? I'm interested.
Person1: What?
Person2: Scams, con games.  How many?
Person1: I don't know.  A lot.
Person2: Whatever kind of nickel-and-dime shit you did before, this is more than just me.  Your friends raided pension plans, and payrolls... they took just over six-hundred million.  You ruined people's lives.

Person1: Yeah, well, me too.
Person2: Trouble with the car again?
Person1: You could say.  I don't even have it yet.
Person2: Darrell giving you problems?
Person1: He did more work on the car.  He wants fifty bucks extra for it.
Person2: Fifty dollars more.  That's a lot of money when you don't have a dime. And where'd you plan on getting the money from?  Maybe you thought you'd pay your friend Jake McKenna a visit.
Person1: It's not like that.
Person2: Maybe you heard old Jake's got some money stashed away and you thought you'd help yourself to a little.
Person1: Wait a minute.  Just listen to me--
Person2: You thought you'd come in here in the middle of the night and wham! Wail off and clock old Jake McKenna and turn his brains into wall paper.
Person1: Jake--
Person2: And then with Jake out of the way you could borrow two-hundred dollars.  Or maybe two-thousand.  Or twenty-thousand.  Who's to stop you? Not Jake McKenna, 'cause old Jake would be dead.
Person1: That's not the reason I'm here.  I swear it.
Person2: There's another reason?  It better be good.
Person1: I came for Grace.
Person2: You came to take my wife from me?
Person1: I came to kill her.
Person2: Liar.
Person1: It's the truth, Jake.
Person2: That's a thick change of heart.
Person1: Yeah, well, a couple of hours ago I just about killed some guy over a girl.  Not for money, for a girl. And she was just going to stand there and let it happen, or let him kill me.  Same way Grace played us this morning.  I don't like that, Jake.  Not twice in one day.  And maybe I'm so pissed I'd twist the next off my own Grandma to get out of here.
Person2: That's a lot of talk.  A whole lot of talk.
Person1: Damn it, Jake.  If I don't get out of here some guys are going to come gunning for me.  And if it comes down to me or Grace, then I pick Grace.  You were going to give me thirteen-thousand.  Give me two- hundred.  I'll kill her and dump the body where no one will ever find it. But I need the money.  I've got to have the money.

Person1: Wrap her up in blankets. Bring the car around to the back of the hotel, throw her off the balcony, put her in the car...Done.

Person1: The reality is, you take away the horror of this situation, take away the tragedy of the death, take away the moral and ethical implications of all the crap you have had conditioned, beaten, into your head since grade one. What are we left with? What? A 115 lb. problem. 115 lbs. that must be moved from point A to point B. Now, a straight line in the shortest distance but we are denied the luxury of a visible straight line. But that line exists and I see it.I see that line. Trust me. Adam. Trust me...I can take care of this.

They couldn't give a flyin' fuck if all the pimps in the whole wide world took two in the back of the head. If you don't get caught at the scene with the smokin' gun in your hand, you got away with it.

No, I ain't talking any business in here.  To me this is holy ground, man.  You understand?  I got to be someplace anyway.  Y'all want to talk, come to the fights tomorrow night, we'll sit down and look at it good. The State Theater.

Person1: I told her she was going to meet her father.
Person2: You what?
Person1: It was the only way, Auggie. Otherwise, she wasn't going to let me see her.
Person2: I think you'd better stop the car and let me out.
Person1: Relax, okay? You don't have to do anything. Just go in there and pretend. It won't kill you to do a little favor like that. Besides, you might even learn something.
Person2: Yeah, like what?

Person2: And what's that supposed to mean?

Person2: Cut it out. Just cut it out, okay? It's starting to get on my nerves.

Person1: You always hurt the ones you love.

Person1: Hey, I've got a great compliment for you.

I'm the only one who appreciates how amazing you are in every single thing you do -- in every single thought you have... in how you are with Spencer -- Spence...  ... in how you say what you mean and how you almost always mean something that's all about being straight and good...

Person1: I'm sorry you can't see that, I know you could once -- you made a little speech once, that I'll always remember and I know the others do too --  They remember and they see how you have changed. That's why they didn't want to come tonight to you, Jabez -- you're as blind as a Burma bat, with your gold pot! Mind you, it's not the money, I've been talking about, it's what you make of it.
Person2: I -- I don't know what you're talking about! I -- I haven't time to listen to all this --
Person1: No -- you haven't time -- You haven't time for your mother, or your wife, or your child.
Person2: It's your fault! You brought Daniel Webster here -- just to try to make a fool of me! You played the sneak behind my back -- made up all sorts of lies against me! You can get yourself out of my home -- go back to the other house -- that old place, where you belong -- I don't want to -- to talk to you again!

Person1: You're wrong.

Person2: Answer yes or no.
Person1: I... No.
Person2: Would you be willing to rig crime scene evidence to support a prosecuting attorney's working hypothesis...?  Yes or no, Edmund.

Person2: Would you be willing to beat confessions out of suspects you knew to be guilty?
Person1: No.

Person1: -- and when my husband died I felt helpless. They disobeyed me -- things went from bad to worse. All my husband's dreams of good health, good sanitation, good morals for these sweet and gentle people seemed to die with him.  Then, almost accidentally, I discovered the secret of how to deal with them. There was a girl with a baby -- again and again I begged her to boil the drinking water. She never would. Then I told her the god, Shango, would be pleased and kill the evil spirits in the water if she boiled it. She boiled the water from then on.
Person2: But you didn't have to come up here.
Person1: Perhaps not.  But I did come here and I found it was so simple to let the gods speak through me. Once started, it seemed such an easy way to do good.  I should have known there was no easy way to do good, Betsy.

Now Rose, the little girl sitting across from you with the blue eyes is Doll Baby. She looks like an angel and she is an angel, but she can be a naughty angel sometimes, although her father won't believe it. Her real name is Frances, but we call her Dolly or Doll.

Granted, ideally, me.  I didn't do it to hurt you.  I did it for you.  I did it for us...

Person2: I -

Person2: What are you -

Person2: I'm only on TV because I gotta be able to hang around the casino. You understand that. You know that. Come on.

Person2: No, it - it - Nicky, when you asked me if you could come out here, what did I tell you? I mean, you asked me, and I knew you were going to come out no matter what I said, but what did I tell you? Do you remember what I told...

Without me, you, personally, every wiseguy skell [Skell: the lowest form of wiseguy - a drunken bum] around'll take a piece of your ass! Then where you gonna go?!  You're warned! Don't ever go over my head again! You motherfucker, you!

Person2: You know?
Person1: Yeah, that's what I'm trying to tell you. That chick Erica?

Person1: I've got what I need for my report. There is... there is one thing that bothers me though.

Person2: No.  You don't have any reason to think that...
Person1: If the police focused their search in her room, her belongings, well that'd be only natural, but they may have been looking in the wrong place.

Person2: All right. That's all.  Please, Matt.

Person1: Fox, Bud D. is this deja vu or has it really been a year. You're not hitting me up for NYU are you?

Person2: Nah, she asked the wrong question.

Person1: Well, uh...
Person2: Sure, sure, that doesn't count. That's different.

Person1: Y'know, you got an awful short memory for direct orders. I told you to stay beside me.
Person2: -- C'mon, Stephen.
Person1: -- You split the team, man. And what was that crap with the standpipe? You'd think you and a hose were never introduced before.

Person1: What was the name of that kid at Anzio, the one who got his face burned off?
Person2: Vecchio.
Person1: Yeah, Vecchio, I couldn't remember his name, he was a good kid, remember how he used to walk on his hands and sing that song about the man on flying trapeze?
Person2: Yeah.
Person1: You know why I'm such a good officer? Because of my mother.  Have I ever told you about her?
Person2: Bits and pieces.
Person1: She's the best poker player you ever saw.  My father used to go to these Saturday night games and lose his shirt.  Finally, my mother gave him an ultimatum, either she gets a regular seat at the table or she locks him in every Saturday night. He squawked and so did his buddies but after a while they gave in and from the first night she sat down, she never lost.  She could read those cocky bastards like they were playing open hands.  And he bluffs?  He had sixteen levels of bullshit.  Her eyes, the tone of her voice, her bets, her jokes, the way she sipped her coffee, she was a master.  She won more money on shit hands than anyone in the history of the game. Every Saturday night, my father would lose two, three hundred bucks and she'd win it all back and then some. And I'd stand there, glued to her shoulder, from the time I was five years old, watching every hand, every move, studying how she did it.  That's why I'm such a good officer, I can look at a man's face and tell you exactly what he's holding, and if it's a shit hand, I know just what cards to deal him.
Person2: And what about your own hand?
Person1: No problem.  A pair of deuces?  Less? So what?  I bluff.  It used to tear me apart when I'd get one of my men killed, but what was I supposed to do?  Break down in front of the ones who were standing there waiting for me to tell them what to do?  Of course not, so I bluffed, and after a while, I started to fall for my own bluff. It was great, it made everything so much easier.  Sarge Is that why your hand's been shaking?
Person1: It could be worse.  You know the first thing they teach you at O.C.S.? Lie to your men.
Person2: Oh, yeah?
Person1: Not in so many words, but they tell you you can have all the firepower in the world and if your men don't have good morale, it's not worth a damn.  So if you're scared or empty or half-a-step from a Section Eight, do you tell your men?  Of course not.  You bluff, you lie.
Person2: And how do you bluff yourself?
Person1: Simple, numbers.  Every time you kill one of your men, you tell yourself you just saved the lives of two, three, ten, a hundred others. We lost, what, thirty-one on the cliffs?  I'll bet we saved ten times that number by putting out those guns.  That's over three hundred men.  Maybe five hundred.  A thousand. Then thousand.  Any number you want. See?  It's simple.  It lets you always choose mission over men.
Person2: Except this time, the mission IS a man.
Person1: That's the rub.  I liked Wade.  Who's Ryan?  If they're both standing in front of me and I have to shoot one or the other, how do I choose?  Look at my hand, there it goes again.
Person2: John, I've got to tell you, I think you're about used up.
Person1: I think you're right, Keith.
Person2: You want me to take over?

Person1: And then, there's Richard's Burrito.
Person2: What's that?
Person1: That's my own theory based on a Mexican food called the burrito. I had it once when my parents took me to Disneyland.
Person2: I know what a burrito is.
Person1: Well, I think time is like a burrito. Sometimes it just folds over on itself and one part touches the other.
Person2: What's inside?
Person1: You can till it with whatever you want. From illusions to memory, from experience to innocence, from happiness to the entire universes
Person2: So you think time travel is possible? For people?
Person1: Absolutely. People, dogs, elephants.
Person2: Listen, you've gotta keep this a secret. You can't tell a soul. Promise?
Person1: Okay. I promise.
Person2: This is serious. Nobody can know. Ah, I've returned from the future. I traveled back here 25 years.
Person1: You probably are crazy. Wait a minute. Is this some kind of joke? I know what you all, think of me.

Person2: I don't know.

Person2: Yes.

Person2: I don't know.
Person1: How about tomorrow? I don't mean to be pushy but --
Person2: I don't know. I don't know what's happening.

Person1: Listen, I want to talk to you.
Person2: Not now.  I don't have time.

Person2: My man?  You told Wyatt you'd Disarmed those men.  Do you Actually believe after that I Could see you as my man?  You're Just a dirty little fixer.

Person1: There's a tunnel out of the crypt into the barn. Did you know about that? There's an answer Mother. That's how she got out.
Person2: That's crazy. How could she find out about it?
Person1: Somebody told her.
Person2: Who?  That tun... that tunnel hasn't been used in fifty years.
Person1: Oh, would you stop lying Mother!
Person2: Why would I lie?
Person1: Because it's murder we're talking about. Aren't you concerned about what she told us about the other person in her room.
Person2: I'm concerned about her health.
Person1: Who was that person Mother?  Was it you?
Person2: If you believe this is murder, it is the Crown attorney you have to talk to, not me. And definitely not Agnes.

Person1: The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars, but in ourselves. Well, let me ask you this: what kind of settlement do you seek? What are, for you, the parameters of the possible?
Person2: That's the problem. I can't afford to give her anything.

Person2: I know that sounds rough but I'm about to close on a deal to develop some mini-malls, and I'm mortgaged up to my ass. If this deal goes south, I'm ruined -- I'll lose millions.
Person1: So, you propose that in spite of demonstrable infidelity on your part, your unoffending wife should be tossed out on her ear?
Person2: Well -- is that possible?

Person1: Want to dance?
Person2: Dance? Here?

Person1: This is not a sexist thing. If you were a waiter I would still be here saying...

I don't get it.  You, my father, here in this house, the cof- fee shop, it's making me upset, and I don't like being upset.  Who are you anyway?  And what are you eating?

Person1: You know, I've always considered myself a very clever girl. Smart. Good head on my shoulders, that sort of thing, never the wrong word at the wrong time... but then, I'd never met Addison deWitt.  I remember once I had a tooth pulled. They gave me some anaesthetic - I don't remember the name - and it affected me in a strange way. I heard myself saying things I wasn't even thinking... as if my mind were someplace outside of my body, and couldn't control what I did or said-
Person2: - and you felt just like that talking to Addison.
Person1: In a way. You find yourself trying to say what you mean, but somehow the words change - and they become his words - and suddenly you're not saying what you mean, but what he means-
Person2: Do you expect me to believe that you didn't say any of those things - that they were all Addison?
Person1: No! I don't expect you to believe anything. Except that the responsibility is mine. And the disgrace.
Person2: Let's not get over-dramatic.
Person1: You've really got a low opinion of me, haven't you? We'll I'll give you some pleasant news. I've been told off in no uncertain terms all over town. Miss Channing should be happy to hear that. To know how loyal her friends are - how much more loyal they are than she had a right to expect me to be...

Person1: Miss Beaufort has accepted our invitation.  By this we can only suppose that she wishes to come -- as we wish her to be here.

Person1: What quaint notions, d'Artagnan! But they contradict my father, who picked his queen when he was old, and only then to bear me.
Person2: There is more to love than he knew, or that you know.

Person2: Not criticize -- plead.  Love.  Love your people, and you will not bear to see them hungry.  Love women, and they will love you.  Love yourself, and --

Person1: His real name is Benjamin Raspail. A former patient of mine, whose romantic attachments ran to, shall we say, the exotic...? I didn't kill him, merely tucked him away. Very much as I found him, in that ridiculous car, in his own garage, after he's missed three appointments. You'd have him under "Missing Person" - which, in poor Raspail's case, could hardly be more true.
Person2: If you didn't kill him, then who did?

Person2: That doesn't interest me, Doctor. And it's the sort of thing Miggs would ask.

Person2: I don't know. Is it?
Person1: Or doesn't this all begin to suggest to you a kind of... negotiation? There's something Crawford can give me, and I want to trade for it. I even wrote to him, offering my help. But he hates me, so he won't deal directly.

Now, now...

He says you're lucky if you can get out while you could still cry.  I should have quit this place  three years ago.

You can't just take a bunch of ignorant peasants and expect them to understand a machine like one of our boys, and I don't mean that as an insult, Mister Ambassador.  Hell, we all know what kind of guts your people have.  Why just look how many millions of 'em those Nazis  killed and, hell, they still wouldn't quit.

A real big plane, like a Sting Ray, zig-zagging in, its jet exhaust frying chickens in the barnyard ---  Has he a chance?.....Hell, yes!  He has one hell of a chance.

And she was found singing and dancing in a cabaret by the man... wait... wait... Ives! His name was Ives!  Yes. And he took her and built for her this great house in the Western Addition... and there was a child. Yes. This was it. The child.

Bigger fish want to eat them. That luminous water -- it takes its gleam from millions of tiny dead bodies. It's the glitter of putrescence.  There's no beauty here -- it's death and decay.

It's so easy to get caught up in the whole ego cycle of this business and make it all about yourself. Stop, right? That's it, no more about me tonight, I promise... Let's talk about you... what do you think about me? I'm kidding... Seriously, Betty, I'm doing all the talking here...

Person1: A layman..., layman. Interesting term. So many experts on government grants. And you say you're a 'layman?' But it was you who caught me, wasn't it, Will? Do you know how you did it'

Person1: Chilton? Gruesome, isn't he? He fumbles at your head like a freshman pulling at a panty girdle.  He actually tries to give me a Thematic and Apperception test. Hah. Sat there waiting for MF-13 to come up. It's a card with a woman in bed and a man in the foreground.  I was supposed to avoid a sexual interpretation. I laughed in his face.  Never mind, it's boring.

Person2: I thought you might be curious to find our if you're smarter than the person I'm looking for.

Person2: You had disadvantages.

Person2: You're insane.
Person1: You're very tan, Will.

Person1: You're a very intelligent girl, Tracy. You have many admirable qualities.  But someday maybe you'll learn that being smart and always being on top and doing whatever you need to do to get ahead, and yes, stepping on people to get there, well, there's a lot more to life than that.  And in the end, you're only cheating yourself.
Person2: Why are you lecturing me?
Person1: This isn't the time or the place to get into it, but there is, for just one example, a certain former colleague of mine, who made a very big mistake, a life mistake.  I think the lesson there is that, old and young, we ail make mistakes, and we have to learn that our actions, all of them, can carry serious consequences.  You're very young, Tracy underage, in fact -- but maybe one day you'll understand.
Person2: I don't know what you're referring to, but I do know that if certain older and wiser people hadn't acted like such little babies and gotten all mushy, everything would be okay.
Person1: I agree.  But I also think certain young and naive people need to thank their lucky stars and be very, very grateful the whole school didn't find out about certain indiscretions which could have ruined their reputations, and chances to win certain elections.
Person2: And I think certain older persons like you and your "colleague" shouldn't be leaching after their students, especially when some of them can't even get their own wives pregnant.  And they certainly shouldn't be running around making slanderous accusations. Especially when certain young, naive people's mothers are para-legal secretaries at the city's biggest law firm and have won many successful lawsuits. And if you want to keep questioning me like this, I won't continue without my attorney present.

Person2: Listen. Listen, Longfellow. You've got brains, kid. You'll get along swell if you'll only curb your homicidal instincts - and keep your trap shut. Don't talk to anybody! These newshounds are out gunning for you.

Person1: I was hoping to get some understanding from you. And I'm not getting it.
Person2: Understanding of what?
Person1: Like I might be in love with another woman.
Person2: In love? Twenty-four hours with some wine-pourer chick and you think you're in love? And give up everything?
Person1: Look who's talking. You've been there.
Person2: Yes I have, and do I look like a happy man? Was all that drama with Brenda a happy thing for me to do? Huh? Was it? Is she a part of my life now?
Person1: This is totally different. I'm talking about avoiding what you're talking about. That's the distinction. I have not made the commitment yet. I am not married. I have not said the words. In a few days, I might get married, and if I do, then I won't be doing stuff like this anymore. Otherwise, what's the whole point of getting married?
Person2: And what about Stephanie? She's a woman -- with a kid. A single mom. What do you think she's looking for? Huh?
Person1: Here's what I'm thinking. We move up here, you and me, buy a vineyard. You design your own wine; I'll handle the business side. Then you get inspired and write a new novel. As for me, if an audition comes along, hell, LA'S two hours away. Not even.

Person2: What? Of course I like Christine.
Person1: You said she was shallow. Yeah, and a nouveau riche.
Person2: That was three years ago after that first party!
