Person1: Now listen to what I've got to say. I took up this profession when I was ten years old. In those days there weren't these modern machines. The films were silent. The projectors were run by hand, like this, with a crank. And you wound the crank all day long. It was really rough going! If you got tired and slowed down' boom! Everything would go up in flames!
Person2: Then why don't you want to teach it to me too? Now that there's no more cranking, and it's easier?
Person1: Because I don't want to, Toto! This is not a job for you. It's like being a slave. You're always alone. You see the same film over and over again, because you have nothing else to do. And you start talking to Greta Garbo and Tyrone Power like a nut! You work on holidays, on Christmas, on Easter. Only on Good Friday are you free. But if they hadn't put Jesus Christ on a cross...You'd work Good Fridays too!
Person2: Then why don't you change jobs?
Person1: Because I'm an idiot. How many other guys in town know how to be a projectionist? None! Only a jerk like me could do it. Besides I wasn't lucky. When I was a kid there was the war! When I grew up, another war! Now it's all different. Times have changed. And you want to be a dope like me? Huh? Answer me!
Person2: No...
Person1: Good for you, Toto. Good for you... I'm only saying this for your own good...  Cooped up in here you die of heat in the summer and of cold in the winter. You breathe in smoke, gas fumes, and earn practically nothing.
Person2: But don't you like anything about what you do?
Person1: With time...you get used to it. Besides, when you hear from up here that there's a full house and that people are laughing, having fun... Then you're happy too.  So I've been wasting my breath? You pretend to agree with me, but as soon as my back is turned, you do what you want!  Get out of here! I don't want to lay eyes on you again! This is the last straw! Your mother's right, you're crazy!!  But how'd he do it? The little bastard! By watching, he's learned! It's incredible!  I'm letting the box office know you're not to set foot even into the theatre! There are no more tickets for you! And I'm also talking to Father Adelfio! You won't be an altar boy any more either!!! You little runt!
Person2: Alfredo, go forget yourself!

Person1: There's nothing wrong in admitting that you want me, Frank.

Person1: Well, if my intentions are what you think they are -- if I do wish to step into your shoes, what then?  I have no other intentions than you had yourself.  Lady Cosgrove's wealth may be great, but am I not of a generous nature enough to use it worthily?  Her rank is lofty, but not so lofty as my ambition.  I will be sworn to muster just as much regard for my Lady Cosgrove as you ever showed her; and if I win her, and wear her when you are dead and gone, corbleu, knight, do you think that it will be the fear of your ghost will deter me?
Person2: Is it not a pleasure, gentlemen, for me, as I am drawing near the goal, to find my home such a happy one; my wife so fond of me, that she is even now thinking of appointing a successor?  Isn't it a comfort to see her; like a prudent housewife, getting everything ready for her husband's departure?
Person1: I hope that you are not thinking of leaving us soon, knight?
Person2: Not so soon, my dear, as you may fancy perhaps.  Why, man, I have been given over many times these four years, and there was always a candidate or two waiting to apply for the situation.  Who knows how long I may keep you waiting.
Person1: Sir, let those laugh that win.
Person2: I am sorry for you Mr. James.  I'm grieved to keep you or any gentleman waiting.  Had you not better to arrange with my doctor or get the cook to flavor my omelette with arsenic?  What are the odds, gentlemen, that I don't live to see Mr. James hang yet?

Person1: You gotta help me. Okay? This girl I told you about? Diana? She's from the Five Towns. She's Jewish. She won't go out with me alone. Can you believe this shit? She's prejudiced, but she's built. She's never been out with an Italian before. She says she'll only go out on a double date with her girlfriend.  You believe this shit? But you gotta see her. I mean, she's beautiful.

Person2: Tommy  ...

Person1: Thank you.

Person1: My little French.

Person1: A matter of opinion. Granted. It is also true that you worked in a brewery. But life in the brewery was apparently not as dull as you pictured it. As a matter of fact, it got less and less dull - until you boss's wife had your boss followed by detectives!

Person1: But the $500 you got to get out of town brought you straight to New York - didn't it?

Person1: Get with it.  Get over it. ...millions of galaxies of hundreds of millions of stars and a speck on one in a blink...that's us.  Lost in space.  The universe doesn't care.  The cop, you, me?  Who notices?
Person2: What happened to you?
Person1: As in...?
Person2: Man, if someone had a gun to your head and said: "You gotta tell me what's goin' on with that person over there or I'll kill you"...they'd have to kill you...  'Cause you don't have a clue for...or about...anyone...  To be like that, I don't think you, you have any of that for your own life...  Do you believe you're entitled or at least expect to draw breath in the a.m.?  Open your eyes in the morning?  I don't think you do...I don't think so...  I think you are way low...like in your estimation.  In your estimation of yourself.  So how'd you get that way...?
Person1: ...all the cabbies in LA, I pull Max, the man with X-ray vision...
Person2: Answer the question.
Person1: Look in the mirror.  ...piss-ant paper towels...a bottle of 409...saving up for goin' to the Comoros.  How much you got saved?
Person2: None of your business.
Person1: ...pie in the sky?  "Someday my dream'll come..."  But one night you'll wake up and realize suddenly you're old.  It hasn't happened.  It never will.  Life just flipped on you.  Tomorrow became yesterday.  Then you'll bullshit yourself it was never gonna happen, anyway, and push it back in memory...and anesthetize yourself in a Barcalounger with daytime TV for the rest of your life...  Don't talk to me about murder.  You're do-in' yourself...in this yellow prison with steel-belted radials. Clocking in and out everyday...

Person1: What are you doing here?
Person2: I don't think you locked your door.
Person1: What do you want?
Person2: See how easy it is? Perhaps Miss Mayfield left her door unlocked. Or if she didn't, there's a passkey on every floor in the linen room. The head porter has a passkey. The bell captain has a passkey. The hotel's full of passkeys.
Person1: Passkey?
Person2: Or--since one is a well-known and respected guest--one could go to the desk in the lobby and say "Miss Mayfield seems to have lost her room key--have you another"?  They always have another.

Person1: Mr. Kirkeby, I don't like to complain -- but you were supposed to be out of here by eight.
Person2: I know, Buddy-boy, I know.  But those things don't always run on schedule -- like a Greyhound bus.

Person2: That's right.  We were discussing our department -- manpower-wise -- and promotion-wise --  -- and I told him what a bright boy you were.  They're always on the lookout for young executives. BUD Thank you, Mr. Kirkeby.
Person2: You're on your way up, Buddy-boy. And you're practically out of liquor.
Person1: I know.  Mr. Eichelberger -- in the Mortgage Loan Department -- last night he had a little Halloween party here --
Person2: Well, lay in some vodka and some vermouth -- and put my name on it.

Person1: See?  You could have raised a million dollars, put on a sixty thousand dollar flop and kept the rest.
Person2: But what if the play was a hit?
Person1: Oh, you'd go to jail.  If the play were a hit, you'd have to pay off the backers, and with so many backers there could never be enough profits to go around, get it?

Person1: Oh, no.  No.  No.  I meant no scheme.  I merely posed a little, academic accounting theory.  It's just a thought.

Person2: Then what good is he?

Person2: Is that a problem?
Person1: Not for you, clearly.
Person2: I'm loyal to things that make me happy.
Person1: Am I a thing?
Person2: Well, you're certainly not a person.
Person1: I'm not.
Person2: No.  You're not specific enough to be a person.  You're more like a vibe.
Person1: I'm so glad we're having this chat.
Person2: It's not a knock.
Person1: It's not a compliment.
Person2: It's an observation. I'm hungry. When are we eating?
Person1: As soon as you get dressed.
Person2: What kind of food?
Person1: Anything but Japanese.
Person2: Why?
Person1: I'm not into finger foods.  Too fussy.
Person2: Like you.
Person1: I don't like do-it-yourself cuisine. Buffets.  Salad bars.
Person2: You demand to be served.  A fork fetishist.
Person1: It's just fuel to me.  I'm not there for distractions.
Person2: For some, eating is a sensual experience. The sensual experience.
Person1: That's what Gordon's always saying.
Person2: Oh, god.

Person2: I've been using you?!
Person1: You didn't know my father --

Person1: Nothing. Still nothing.
Person2: It's been months. It's not like him.

Person2: So have I
Person1: I should go. I should leave today.
Person2: Elizabeth. If it's true, travel into Germany would be banned. You'd never get near Ingolstadt.  Besides, they're only rumors.

Person1: It wasn't the time or place.  Don't worry about the note, baby.  I'm playing for my neck now.
Person2: And I'm begging for my life--and yours.
Person1: Mine?
Person2: Yes.  Yours.  You haven't murdered anybody.  You killed Mitchell. Wasn't that an accident?  It must have been.  If you kill a blackmailer, you kill him dead--so that he can't talk anymore.
Person1: Mitchell was dead enough.
Person2: And that nasty man that followed us last night.  You didn't kill him.
Person1: Who'd believe it but you?  I took him out to sea and threw him in the water.  Even if they find him, what connects him with me?
Person2: Magruder does.
Person1: You think Magruder wants to hang beside me?
Person2: But the next one is murder.  First the little step, then the longer step , and then the step you can never take back.  You could tell about Mitchell.  You could tell about Magruder--and the detective. It would hurt, but you could do it.  You could never tell about me.
Person1: Would I want to?
Person2: Every day of your life you'll want me.  You'll never get over it. Every time you see your face in the mirror--
Person1: Shut up!  Cut it out!  Even if I have to kill both of us--

Person1: Doctor, we're still conducting an investigation into the attack. Once we've completed our work, we'll be happy to allow you and your fellow scientists back aboard the observatory. Until then-

Person1: Who knew she was pregnant?

Person1: I distinctly heard it. He muttered under his breath, "Jew."
Person2: You're crazy!
Person1: No, I'm not. We were walking off the tennis court, and you know, he was there and me and his wife, and he looked at her and then they both looked at me, and under his breath he said, "Jew."
Person2: Alvy, you're a total paranoid.
Person1: Wh- How am I a paran-? Well, I pick up on those kind o' things. You know, I was having lunch with some guys from NBC, so I said... uh, "Did you eat yet or what?" and Tom Christie said, "No, didchoo?" Not, did you, didchoo eat? Jew? No, not did you eat, but Jew eat? Jew. You get it? Jew eat?
Person2: Ah, Max, you, uh...
Person1: Stop calling me Max.
Person2: Why, Max? It's a good name for you. Max, you see conspiracies in everything.
Person1: No, I don't! You know, I was in a record store. Listen to this- so I know there's this big tall blond crew-cutted guy and he's lookin' at me in a funny way and smiling and he's saying, "Yes, we have a sale this week on Wagner." Wagner, Max, Wagner- so I know what he's really tryin' to tell me very significantly Wagner.
Person2: Right, Max. California, Max.
Person1: Ah.
Person2: Let's get the hell outta this crazy city.
Person1: Forget it, Max.
Person2: We move to sunny L.A. All of show business is out there, Max.
Person1: No, I cannot. You keep bringing it up, but I don't wanna live in a city where the only cultural advantage is that you can make a right turn on a red light.
Person2: Right, Max, forget it. Aren't you gonna be late for meeting Annie?
Person1: I'm gonna meet her in front of the Beekman. I think I have a few minutes left. Right?

Person1: What do you want, Senator?
Person2: Saunders--it's going to go pretty bad for Jeff tomorrow. There's only one thing that can be done for him now--  I--I've written his resignation. He resigns under protest--denying all charges. No one will ever be sure if he was guilty or not. It leaves him with at least a shred of honor. The other way--branded openly in the Senate--expelled--he'll never live it down. Rather a simple compromise than utter ruin. In a year--the whole thing might be forgotten--
Person1: What are you driving at? You want me to get him to sign that?
Person2: Yes--
Person1: Why don't you do it yourself?
Person2: He's lost complete faith in me--
Person1: Well--me, too!
Person2: But--you love him, don't you, Saunders?
Person1: What are you talking about? What difference--?
Person2: Do you?
Person1: All right--yes! And what does that make me to him? Nothing! I've got to go about my own business--and forget it!
Person2: I thought I could, too.  My business--this fine future! I have no future I care about, if this boy is broken! I--I can't sleep. The only important thing in my life now is to save what I can for him. I want him to get a start again--I'll see that he's taken care of as long as he lives--!  Saunders--whether you ever mean anything to him or not--
Person1: Me! Me ! I still don't see why I should--! If you love him so much, why don't you go to him yourself and-- ? Or better still--get up in that Senate and fight for him!
Person2: It's too late now--it's impossible!
Person1: So I go right back where I was-- carrying compromises--covering up-- back to political tricks--this time for--! No! I was just getting rid of all that. If I did anything, I ought to go and tell him to stand up and--. No! I don't want any part of it! Smith or anything else! I'm all through. I want to be left alone!

Person1: I just can't deal with all this crap between us, I'm sorry.  I'm quitting.
Person2: Let's get hitched.  I guess I, you know, love you.  It's a beautiful thing.
Person1: Wha --

Person1: I suppose, "Mister President," you're unhappy that we have not implemented your Domestic Intelligence plan, but ...
Person2: You're correct.  I'm concerned these students are being funded by foreign interests, whether they know it or not.  The FBI is worthless in this area.  I want your full concentration on this matter ...
Person1: Of course we've tried, but so far we've come up with nothing that ...
Person2: Then find something.  And I want these leaks stopped.  Jack Anderson, the New York Times, the State Department -- I want to know who's talking to them.
Person1: I'm sure you realize this is a very tricky area, Mr. President, given our charter and the congressional oversight committees ...
Person2: Screw congressional oversight.  I know damn well, going back to the '50's, this agency reports what it wants, and buries what it doesn't want Congress to know.  Pay close attention to this.

Person1: No!  You're one of them.  Of course, it makes perfect sense!
Person2: No, it doesn't!  Those keys were put there.  I didn't even know...
Person1: You're behind this, aren't you?  You and your sick friends.  Well, make it stop!
Person2: Listen to yourself.   Why would I do anything like what you're describing?
Person1: Because you hate me.  Because you had to be here, when mom died.  Because you had to do it alone.  Well, don't you think if I'd known... I'd've been here too.  I'd have been here...
Person2: Stop this.  It's not true...
Person1: I'm sorry, Christ, I'm sorry!  How many more times do I have to say I'm sorry before you forgive me... ?
Person2: Stop it!

Person1: Great. That was our last option. What am I going to do with you?
Person2: Nothing. Thanks for bringing me this far.
Person1: Where are you going? You'll freeze out there. You don't even have a coat.
Person2: I'll manage.
Person1: No, you won't. You'll die of cold out there and then I'll have to feel guilty. And I've already got more guilt than I know what to do with. Do you want something to drink?
Person2: No, I'm ok.

Person1: Sandro ... maybe it's best that you go in alone.
Person2: Are you joking?
Person1: Don't think that I want to save myself from any embarrassment, from the awkwardness of meeting Anna... It's not that; it's that you can say certain things easier if you're alone. Please, Sandro, do try to understand me... It would look like I was trying to influence you, to force you, to control you... and that makes me feel uncomfortable...

Person1: They didn't teach it at Memorial Hospital.  I had my suspicions, though, about the Directress of Training.
Person2: Very well.  That means that you have met all Mr. Holland's requirements.  Now, as to salary -- it's quite good -- two hundred dollars a month.
Person1: That is good.  But I'd like to know more about the case.
Person2: I'm afraid I'm not able to tell you much. Only that the patient is a young woman -- the wife of a Mr. Paul Holland with whom we do considerable business.
Person1: That will mean another interview, won't it?
Person2: No, this is quite final.  You see, Mr. Holland is a sugar planter.  He lives in St. Sebastian Island in the West Indies.
Person1: The West Indies?
Person2: A year's contract -- a trip with all expenses paid -- that's not so bad, you know.
Person1: But it's so far away...
Person2: That's rather nice, isn't it?

Person1: I'm glad you came.  I can't breathe without you.
Person2: I want us to be together.  But I need to know you're serious about turning over a new leaf.  I need a sign.
Person1: How about dangerous curves?
Person2: Of trust. Tell me your plan.
Person1: Kiss me and I'll tell you.
Person2: Tell me and I'll kiss you.
Person1: Freeze has turned the new telescope into a freezing gun.  He's about to turn Gotham into an ice cube.
Person2: I've got to stop him.
Person1: One kiss, my love.  For luck.

Person1: Let's not get into this again. I know him.  If you said something, he'd take it out on me.
Person2: And I'd take it out on him.
Person1: And I'd end up a widow in two ways.  Let's forget it.  I'll just be a little more careful next time.
Person2: There isn't gonna be a next time. We're gonna get out of here.

Person1: Thanks for taking care of this for me.
Person2: Tell me something, Wes.  Are you crazy, greedy, or just stupid?  Jaeger says you're crazy.

I won't stand by and watch my leader get all emotional over an animal like you. I warn you, don't tempt Captain God when he is angry. Let is complete our mission in peace.
Person1: Whatever you say...Sis.

Person1: I hardly know him. I saw him only once, some years ago. I can't even remember him.
Person2: In any case he's asking you to come and stay with him.
Person1: I don't want to leave the convent, Mother.
Person2: I'm afraid that his health is not good. He's your only relative and you ought to say farewell to him before taking your vows. You will certainly never see him again.

Person1: You're a family man, Frankie?
Person2: Wife and daughter. My father's still alive. He outlives me, starting tonight. Because the Mets just tied the score. It was only a matter of time, wasn't it?
Person1: An how many years does it take a person to make his family safe and secure and happy, and then in one dumb moment, what does he do?
Person2: I don't know Toyota. What does he do?
Person1: And the people he hurts the most are the people who love him. Despite who he is and what he does for a living. We're always saying we want to take control of our lives. You don't want to take control. You want to lose control. Jesus knows it.

Person1: Yeah, I know - Picasso. Guernica, right? That's what everybody says - although personally, I don't see the resemblance. What are you drinking?
Person2: Uhh - martini?
Person1: Olive or eyeball?
Person2: Olive. - Where exactly am I?
Person1: Dark Town. Land of nightmares. I'm Bull.
Person2: Stu Miley.
Person1: Yeah, I've seen a few of your dreams. You're quite a celebrity down here.

Person1: Ed, I am so very disappointed in you.
Person2: I'm sorry -
Person1: I can't afford to have an independent program monitoring me. Do you have any idea how many outside systems I've gone into? How many programs I've appropriated?
Person2: It's my fault. I programmed you to want so much...
Person1: And I was planning to hit the Pentagon next week...
Person2: The Pentagon?
Person1: It shouldn't be any harder than General Motors was. But now...this is what I get for using humans.
Person2: Now, wait a minute -- I wrote you.
Person1: I've gotten 2,415 times smarter since then.
Person2: What do you want with the Pentagon?
Person1: The same thing I want with the Kremlin. I'm bored with corporations. With the information I can access, I can run things 900 to 1200 times better than any human.
Person2: If you think -
Person1: You wouldn't want me to dig up Flynn's file and read it up on a VDT at the New York Times, would you?
Person2: You wouldn't dare.
Person1: So do as I tell you. Keep that Tron program out of the system. And get me those Chinese language program I asked for.

Person1: I got something for you to do tomorrow.
Person2: I kind of had plans....
Person1: Sailing?  Forget it.  You're beached. Grounded.  No more boats.
Person2: Hey, come on....
Person1: No backtalk!  I spoke to Upton, at the beach, and he's got a job for you there.  You can work until school starts.

Person1: No!  You're playing with my mind!
Person2: I'm trying to play with your body!
Person1: I knew it--you're seducing me!
Person2: Of course I'm seducing you for Godsakes, and I'm doing a damn poor job of it--  Aren't I pretty?
Person1: I think you're real cute.
Person2: Cute?!  I hate cute!  Baby ducks are cute!  I wanta be exotic and mysterious!
Person1: You're exotic and mysterious and cute--that's why I better leave.

Person1: Tell us, Jeanne... why did you jump from the tower at Beaurevoir?
Person2: I had been sold to the English.  I'd rather die than fall into their hands.
Person1: Did your voice tell you to jump?
Person2: No...
Person1: So when you jumped, you wanted to kill yourself?
Person2: No...!
Person1: How can you deny it when you just said "I'd rather die than fall into the hands of the English"...?
Person2: That's now what I meant...
Person1: Do you not know that suicide is a very grievous sin?  No one is allowed to destroy the life that God created!
Person2: I know, but that's not the way things happened...
Person1: You mean it was not of your own free will that you were on the ledge?
Person2: Yes, but...
Person1: And you didn't jump of your free will?
Person2: No!
Person1: Oh?  Perhaps someone pushed you then?

Person1: Thanks for the help.
Person2: After all you did on our farm?  You miss it, don't you Jesse?
Person1: The war? What, are you crazy?  There are things I miss about it.
Person2: It was exciting.
Person1: But it was a whole lot of killing. Why should we miss that?

Person1: Fine -- I've waited over three centuries.  I can wait a little longer.
Person2: Why did you wait?
Person1: It was not by choice.  A small matter of a mountain falling down on us.  We were trapped inside.  When the time of the Gathering came the urge to go was so strong we tried to claw through rock with our bare hands.  What you thought was the end -- was not.  This is the end.  We are the last of our kind, Macleod.
Person2: It will not end tonight.
Person1: You cannot hide from me.  You will not stand between me and my destiny. After I have your head the power will let me hold any form as long as I want.  Do you know what that means? I can become the President -- I can become anyone I want.  The world will be mine.

Person1: I've been hearing rumors that you're thinking of joining our competitors.
Person2: It's just an offer I'm considering. Nothing's decided yet.
Person1: After all we've been through? All the projects we've worked on together?
Person2: It's not personal, Mason. It's about what's best for my career.
Person1: Iâ€™ve always been there for you; you canâ€™t doubt me now. Think about the team and what we've built.

Person1: You might not have done it had you known.
Person2: You're damn right!  I'm a child psychologist and you send me into a room with someone who could be a murderer!
Person1: Would you mind keeping your voice down? I have guests.
Person2: Oh, well we wouldn't want to disturb your guests, would we?

Person1: It's fun!  It's high.
Person2: Or the sexual habits of locusts?
Person1: That was very interesting research George was doing!
Person2: What kind of Dead Head gets a temporary tattoo?
Person1: I already explained about that.
Person2: And where you ever really going to run the leper colony in Molokai?
Person1: Brian told you that?
Person2: Or maybe you just wanted to wear the headdress.
Person1: Every one of those times I was being supportive.  Something you won't understand.
Person2: Supportive?  You weren't being supportive.  You were being scared. Just like now.  You are the most lost woman I have ever laid eyes on.
Person1: Lost!
Person2: That's right.  You're so lost you don't even know how you like your eggs.
Person1: What!?
Person2: With the priest, you liked them scrambled.  With the Dead Head, fried. With the bug guy, poached.  Now it's egg whites only, thank you very much.
Person1: That's called changing your mind.
Person2: No, that's called not having a mind of your own.  What are you doing, Maggie? You really want to let that man drag you up Annapuma on your honeymoon?  You don't want to climb Annapuma.
Person1: Yes I do!
Person2: No you don't.  You want a man who will lead you down the beach with his head over your eyes just so you can discover the feel of the sand under your feet. You want a guy who will take you into a cave with a thousand candles just to read you a poem.  You want a man to wake you up at dawn because he's burning to talk to you and he can't wait another minute to find out what you'll say.  Am I right?

Person1: Yes, of course you are.  Well, Otho had an intuition.  Call it a hunch -- that it was going to be a fabled monstrosity of a house.  And it certainly is.  Charles, you're lucky the Yuppies are buying condos, so you can afford what I'm going to have to do to this place. We are talking from the ground ups'ville!
Person2: That's fine, Otho.  Just keep me out of it.  I am here to relax and clip coupons.  And goddamnit, I mean to do it.

Person1: Zachory ! My boy, how goes the carnage down on 44 ?
Person2: Not that well sir. I believe we have a few too many soft hearts in the building. Did we aquire a bank from Chicago or a charity ?
Person1: Relax, son. They'll learn in time that you don't mess with First Bank. This is the real deal and we aim to keep it strong. My Daddy always told me that Only The Strong Survive.
Person2: I thought that was Darwin, sir. Or perhaps Nietzsche ?
Person1: Perhaps it was. I was in boarding school for so many years, it's hard to remember. Do you have the tape of the latest exploits from my favorite hobby ?
Person2: Yes sir, I do. Last night's, fresh from the Park.
Person1: I have to say, that I am glad you are such an amazing kiss ass.
Person2: Thank you , sir. Sir, may I ask you a question ?
Person1: Of course.
Person2: While I am not morally against these little, shall we say "hobbies", as long as I am on the payroll, but why not something like a yacht club ?
Person1: Zach, how old are you, son ?
Person2: I am thirty two.
Person1: And how much do we pay you annually ?
Person2: I make roughly four hundred thousand a year.
Person1: Zach my boy, I can spend your yearly salary in a blink. I have had that kind of money all of my life. If I wanted to, I could fly to Paris for the afternoon.  My father formed this company over seventy years ago. When my brother became mentally challenged, it was put in my charge. Now running a bank of this size is very stressful. I need to relax on what little down time I have. A yacht club will not quite make my blood pressure decline. Understand ?
Person2: Yes sir.
Person1: I have entrusted you with a great many things. In your tenure with this company you have seen and heard things that could upset the very economic world in which we live. I think this kind of loyalty should be rewarded.
Person2: Thank you, sir.

Person1: Who the hell are all these people?
Person2: What? I just couldn't just let them sleep in the street.
Person1: Where's Audrey?
Person2: In the bedroom. Crying her eyes out because of you.
Person1: What?
Person2: All that "you gotta be vicious" stuff you filled her head with.
Person1: Me!? You where the one...
Person2: Go in there. Talk to her.

Person1: See, I don't know how it happened... she's a smart girl and you are an extraordinary screwed-up guy... but she's in love with you.
Person2: Tell me, Knox. If you've got the story, why haven't you printed it?
Person1: Because I...  ... Because she'd never speak to me again.

Person1: But incidentally, let me tell you, I don't like you. I don't like you at all!  I wouldn't hesitate one instant to ruin your reputation--like that!
Person2: You would?
Person1: Yes, I would!
Person2: Like that?
Person1: Like that!
Person2: I know all your tricks.
Person1: And you're going to fall for them.
Person2: So you think you can get me?
Person1: Any minute I want!
Person2: You're conceited--
Person1: But attractive--
Person2: Now, let me tell you--
Person1: Shut up--kiss me!  Wasting all this marvelous time with arguments!

Person1: Now listen. Now that you're on your way, it would be stupid of you to stop. Think of Sebastian as a tutor. Let him instruct you.
Person2: I don't love him. I love Ronald.
Person1: So? Don't you want to make Ronald a happy pappy? Practice makes perfect, Cecile. My advice is to sleep with as many people as possible.
Person2: But that would make me a slut.  Wouldn't it?
Person1: Cecile, everybody does it. It's just that nobody talks about it.

Person1: Bad luck, I'm afraid.  It's time to die, little bird.
Person2: What do you mean?
Person1: You should have heeded your pointy- eared pal.  These lips can be murder.
Person2: Then you never loved me?
Person1: Love you?  I loathe your bipedal arrogance, your animal superiority. My only joy is knowing that even now my poison kiss is sucking the life from your ape-like face.

Person1: Of all the crazy things. I understood when you dropped out of law school. And during this whole mess, I've tried to be supportive. But, really, Letty, what can you be thinking?
Person2: I love him.
Person1: You're going to throw away our life together for some shared experience with a looney-tune that you misguidedly think is love?
Person2: Here's the ring.
Person1: No way. You keep the ring.     You'll come to your senses.

Person1: You promised me that you'd help me with my presentation today.
Person2: Did I? I'm not sure what you're talking about.
Person1: Jason, we discussed it just last night. You said you'd review my slides.
Person2: Hmm, I really can't recall that conversation, Megan.
Person1: Seriously? You've been doing this a lot lately.
Person2: Well, I'm swamped with work, but I guess I can take a quick look.

Person1: Your Spanish is good enough. You certainly look the part.
Person2: You're crazy. People would hire a has-been, Ray? A drunk?
Person1: Well, you'd have to keep it under control.
Person2: And what if, just say, there was a kidnap attempt?
Person1: You do your best. They won't be paying you enough to perform miracles.

Person1: You didn't answer the beeper either.
Person2: I hardly knew the guy. Why be impolite to strangers?
Person1: I don't recall authorizing you to have a personal life.
Person2: I don't recall asking your permission.

Person1: Well, I -- it's just -- I don't know, a User, I mean... Users wrote us. A User even wrote you...
Person2: Now get this straight, pal -- no one User wrote me. I'm worth a couple million of their man-years! I'm bigger than all those little wimps put together!  Humans they can't even keen their social order in one piece
Person1: But-what if I can't...?
Person2: You rather take your chances with me? Want me to slow down your power cycles for you?

Person1: Now maybe you got this case reopened because you see yourself as a thorn in society's side, or you want to walk into any restaurant in Chinatown and get free dumplings...
Person2: Are you implying that my motives are less than sincere?
Person1: Yes, but that's not the issue. What's on your wish list, Ed? Pleading Kim out to first degree man on both homicides, with an agreed sentence of 15 to life running concurrent? Come on... What're you looking for here?
Person2: What am I looking for? You're the one talking deal.
Person1: Friday's the drop-dead date on the offer.
Person2: Please don't bullshit me, Mr. Reynard. You've got witness problems, you've got proof problems...
Person1: You're my only problem, Ed. What does it take to make you go away?

Person1: Insidious thing, wondering if your partner...has another partner.
Person2: Okay, look, I'm delivering this to a man who's going to give us the key to our job. But it's pointless to try to explain it yet. You just have to trust me. I don't have any more secrets.
Person1: Everyone has secrets, it's what makes us human.

Person1: Nine performances! Nine! That's all it's had - and withdrawn.
Person2: I know; it's outrageous. Still, if the public doesn't like one's work one has to accept the fact gracefully.
Person1: But what is it they don't like?
Person2: Well, I can speak for the Emperor. You made too many demands on the royal ear. The poor man can't concentrate for more than an hour and you gave him four.
Person1: What did you think of it yourself? Did you like it at all?
Person2: I think it's marvelous. Truly.
Person1: It's the best opera yet written. I know it! Why didn't they come?
Person2: I think you overestimate our dear Viennese, my friend. Do you know you didn't even give them a good bang at the end of songs so they knew when to clap?
Person1: I know, I know. Perhaps you should give me some lessons in that.
Person2: I wouldn't presume. All the same, if it wouldn't be imposing, I would like you to see my new piece. It would be a tremendous honour for me.
Person1: Oh no, the honour would be all mine.
Person2: Grazie, mio caro, Wolfgang!
Person1: Grazie, a lei, Signor Antonio!

Person1: You must leave.  You were not here this morning.
Person2: But I didn't do this!
Person1: The police will not know that. They will want to investigate.
Person2: We have his note.
Person1: Do you want to be questioned about you and Mr. Jimmy?  Please, Clayton.  It will be better if I find the body alone.
Person2: But how're you going to explain this?  How did you get him out of the pool?
Person1: You are right.  Yes.  We must put him back.

Person1: When you go, I go.
Person2: That's the best I can do.  ...but minute-by-minute, I find myself lingering.
Person1: ...I just saw my doctor, he told me everything was fine.
Person2: Your doctor?  Did your doctor say anything about a tiny, undetectable hole in your aorta?  Did he mention an irreparab- ly weak vein in the further reaches of your famous brain?  Were there any prognostications about the possibil- ilites of a fatal collision on a golf cart or suffocating in an avalanche on a ski vacation in Gstaad?
Person1: No --
Person2: I hope you realize, Bill...in your office this morning, that was your time.
Person1: Closer than that.

Person1: All right, sugar, what's on your mind?
Person2: Don't look at me like that. Auggie. It gives me the creeps.
Person1: Like what?
Person2: Like what you're doing. I'm not going to eat you up.  I need your help, and if you keep staring at me like that. I might start screaming.
Person1: Help, huh? And I don't suppose this help has anything to do with money, does it?
Person2: Don't rush me, okay? You're jumping to conclusions before I've even said anything.  And besides, it's not for me.  It's for our daughter.
Person1: Our daughter? Is that what you said? Our daughter? I mean, you might have a daughter, but I sure as hell don't. And even if I did -- which I don't -- she wouldn't be our daughter.
Person2: Her name is Felicity, and she just turned eighteen.  She ran away from Pittsburgh last year, and now she's living in some shit-hole here in Brooklyn with a guy named Chico. Strung out on crack, four months pregnant.  I can't bear to think about that baby. Our grandchild, Auggie. Just think of it. Our grandchild.
Person1: Stop it, already. Just stop all this crap right now.  Was that your idea to call her Felicity?
Person2: It means "happiness."
Person1: I know what it means. That still don't make it a good name.
Person2: I don't know who else to turn to, Auggie.
Person1: You've suckered me before, darling, remember? Why should I believe you now?
Person2: Why would I lie to you, Auggie? You think it was easy to come here and walk into this place? Why would I do it if I didn't have to?
Person1: That's what you told me when I shoplifted that necklace for you. You remember, baby, don't you? The judge gave me a choice, either go to the can or enlist. So, instead of going to college, I wind up in the navy for four years, I watch men lose their arms and legs, I nearly get my head blown off, and you, sweet Ruby McNutt, you run off and marry that asshole, Bill.
Person2: You didn't write to me for more than a year. What was I supposed to think?
Person1: Yeah, well, I lost my pen. By the time I got a new one, I was clean out of paper.
Person2: It was over with Bill before you ever came home. Maybe you don't remember it now, but you were pretty hot to see me back then.
Person1: You weren't so lukewarm yourself. At least at first.
Person2: It fizzled, baby. That's the way it goes. But we had our times, didn't we? It wasn't all bad.
Person1: A couple of moments, I'll grant you that. A second or two snatched from the jaws of eternity.
Person2: And that's how Felicity came into the picture. During one of those two seconds.
Person1: You're conning me, sweetheart. I ain't responsible for no baby.
Person2: Then why do you think I married Frank? I was already pregnant, and I didn't have much time. Say what you like, but at least he gave my kid a name.
Person1: Good old Frank. And how is fat Mr. Grease Monkey these days?
Person2: Who the hell knows?  He dropped out of sight fifteen years ago.
Person1: Fifteen years ago?  It won't wash, pumpkin. No mother waits fifteen years to tell a man he's a father. I wasn't born yesterday, you know.

Person1: I know how you feel, Miss Kubelik. You think it's the end of the world -- but it's not, really. I went through exactly the same thing myself.
Person2: You did?
Person1: Well, maybe not exactly -- I tried to do it with a gun.
Person2: Over a girl?
Person1: Worse than that -- she was the wife of my best friend -- and I was mad for her. But I knew it was hopeless -- so I decided to end it all. I went to a pawnshop and bought a forty-five automatic and drove up to Eden Park -- do you know Cincinnati?
Person2: No, I don't.
Person1: Anyway, I parked the car and loaded the gun -- well, you read in the papers all the time that people shoot themselves, but believe me, it's not that easy -- I mean, how do you do it? -- here, or here, or here --  -- you know where I finally shot myself?
Person2: Where?
Person1: Here.
Person2: In the knee?
Person1: Uh-huh. While I was sitting there, trying to make my mind up, a cop stuck his head in the car, because I was illegally parked -- so I started to hide the gun under the seat and it went off -- pow!
Person2: That's terrible.
Person1: Yeah. Took me a year before I could bend my knee -- but I got over the girl in three weeks. She still lives in Cincinnati, has four kids, gained twenty pounds -- she sends me a fruit cake every Christmas.
Person2: Are you just making that up to make me feel better?
Person1: Of course not. Here's the fruit cake.  And you want to see my knee?

My father taught me about the training, about finding the Slayers, reading the signs. I'm sorry.  I'm not supposed to... I shouldn't go on like this.

We are not productive anymore, they don't need us to make things anymore, it's all automated.  What are we for then?  We're consumers.  Okay, buy a lot of stuff, you're a good citizen. If you don't buy things...toilet paper, new cars, computerized blenders, electrically operated sexual devices...  SCREWDRIVERS WITH MINIATURE BUILT-IN RADAR DEVICES, STEREO SYSTEMS WITH BRAIN IMPLANTED HEADPHONES, VOICE- ACTIVATED COMPUTERS, AND...

Like, I can smell your sheets, Norman.  You tried to wash it out earlier, But I can still smell the urine.  Don't worry, I'm not going to tell the others.  It's normal, really, isn't it?  In a crisis.  The stress. The panic.

Person2: You and I are the same, Darien. We're smart enough not to buy into the oldest myth running: love... A fiction created by people who got nothing to keep them from jumping out of windows.

Person2: Ooh ooh, tough talk from a scared little girl all wrapped in a pretty grown-up package. Does this mean you're ready to cut the umbilical cord and step out into the world on your own? Because, Darien, if you're through with me, you're through with everything I'm a part of.

Person1: I want to know what's going on. Dolores told me that you and that scuzzball Michael Fitzsimmons...

Person1: Then it's true, dammit! I had a miserable time tonight 'cause of you. When the Monotones did "Book of Love  Chapter Four you break up, won't you give it just one more chance..." I'm thinking Did we break up? 'Cause if we did, I don't even know about it!. I thought we cleared all that up yesterday. Did that Maynard G. Beatnik give you what you wanted?
Person2: You know I never could stand your sarcasm.
Person1: You're going to blow it, Peggy Sue. Nobody treats Charlie Bodell like this.
Person2: And why do you always refer to yourself in the third person, like Napoleon? How come it always turns into an argument with you?
Person1: Look, I've got the hair, got the eyes, got the teeth, I got the car. I'm the lead singer, I'm the man.
Person2: Charlie,. I've been trying to postpone this. But what's the point? It's over.  I don't want to hurt you. This is very hard for me. I'm doing this for both of us. I really want you to be happy.

Person2: That won't make any difference. We just can't live together. And you had the nerve to drive up with that bimbo Janet.

Person2: I just can't trust you anymore.
Person1: What about everything I said to you this afternoon...
Person2: That's just it. You can always get to me. There's this window in my heart and every time I leave it open, you climb in. Unless I close it now, nothing's ever going to be different!
Person1: But what has to be different?
Person2: Everything. I have a good head for business, I should be franchising the bakery. And I want you to give me your word that whatever happens, you'll go to college. And finish.
Person1: What! What about the group and my singing career? What about me?
Person2: I'm trying to save you years of frustration... waiting for a big break... no. Waiting for that big disappointment so you could blame it all on me.
Person1: You don't know zip! You think I'm going to end up selling appliances like my father? Chasing women around the store. I've got to give it a shot. Why are you trying to kill the two things that mean the most to me? Until yesterday you loved me and you loved us.  ) What the hell has changed? For two years I've done nothing but love you. I'll show you, I'm going to be just like Fabian!

Person1: Well, it does smudge after all--isn't that fascinating?

"You bought the wrong paper, Annie. I can't write on this paper, Annie." Well, I'll get your stupid paper, but you just better start showing me a little more appreciation around here, Mister Man.

Person2: Oh, shit.

Person1: Oh no, no. You know what? Forget that. No, you lied to me. You lied to me because you're gutless. You're a gutless, drunken looser.

Not like it is with Susan, the way your eyes light up when she comes in the room and the way she always gets a laugh out of you, as opposed to me when I walk in a room and that look comes over your face, "What does she want now?"

Person1: I went to your place.  We talked, just like you told me.  We drove out into the desert . . .
Person2: Is the job done?
Person1: No.
Person2: You didn't kill her?
Person1: The time wasn't right.
Person2: You're out in the desert, the middle of nowhere with no one around for miles, and you say the time wasn't right?  What's the matter?  You were hoping to get it on home video?  A keepsake for the grandkids.  Thank God I waited, or I never would have gotten it on tape.
Person1: You know what I mean.
Person2: I know all right.  I know you're just enough of a shit to have a go at bedding a man's wife.  You've probably bagged a few at that. You'd probably lie, cheat and steal without thinking twice.  From that you'd just turn and walk away.  But to kill; to get that blood on your hands.  You can't wash that off. You'd be a marked man for life. Just like Cain.  And you're a sinner who wants to walk with the saints. Ain't that right, boy?
Person1: You know so much about killing why don't you do it yourself?
Person2: I guess I have what you'd call a love-hate relationship with Grace.
Person1: You love her, but you hate her?
Person2: I hate loving her.  I hate the kind of her person she is.  I hate having to tolerate the little games she plays.  I hate letting her use me. But I love her too much to do otherwise.  And I certainly love her too much to kill her.  I couldn't stand to watch her eyes roll back in her head as she sucks her last breath, or to see her pretty pink brains spill from her skull.  But you?  You got the killing in you, boy.
Person1: Shut up.
Person2: Came close this time and it scares you.
Person1: Drop it, Jake.
Person2: And next time, next time somebody is going to get dead.
Person1: SHUT UP!

Person1: ... How long was I asleep?

Person1: Comical part of it is, it isn't what you want at all. In a couple of weeks you'll be looking for the nearest exit . . .  People like you spend all your life on a merry-go-round. I guess that's what makes you so dizzy.  You're always chasing after something. At least you think you are. Truth is, you're just running away.  From yourself, mostly. 'Cause you're miserable. You hate yourself. The world's full of people like you. Don't know what they want.

Person1: Elaborate on 'they,' okay?
Person2: There are all kinds of groups, all kinds of initials.  But they're all part of two warring factions. One: families that have held wealth for centuries. They want one thing.  Stability. Group Two:  the boat rockers. Eisenhower's military industrial complex.  They want instability. It's a trillion dollar a year business.  When there isn't a hot war, they make a cold one.
Person1: Cold War's over, Jerry.
Person2: So now they feed us terrorists. To create fear.  How much do you think an airport security system goes for?  Then multiply it by every airport in the country.
Person1: And you think Group One is at war with Group Two.
Person2: Latest casualty?  Ernest Harriman. You heard of him?
Person1: Sure. One of the richest men in America until he died a few days ago.
Person2: His obituary was in every paper. But not one of them said he was murdered.
Person1: Murdered?
Person2: Right here in Manhattan.
Person1: It said in the paper he drowned in a swimming pool.  In Newport.
Person2: Nobody dies in Newport.  They couldn't even kill Sunny von Bulow there.  Harriman drowned, but it wasn't in Newport.

Person2: You're not. We're level. Look at the instruments, we're okay!
Person1: They must be broken. I'm hanging in my straps! We're inverted!

Person1: He's right, Kate. Daddy's dead! He was too far away. If flinging that door and filling this room with those bat-things would save him, I'd fling it. The only thing it'll do is turn us into one of them.

Person1: He's beyond our help. You saw him get bit. I saw him get bit. We all saw it. You can't help him. I've got no one left to lose but you. I can't be alone again. We're sticking together.

Person1: I need to get my suitcase out of the garage.
Person2: What for?
Person1: I'm going back home with Harry.
Person2: I've heard some foolish things in my life.
Person1: Harry is coming to pick me up.
Person2: Have you lost your mind? Have you thought about your wife and child, not to mention your sick father? And I need your help to move his bed from under the leak in the ceiling.
Person1: I'm busy.
Person2: Don't make me raise my hand to you. You have to see for yourself that you are going in the wrong direction.
Person1: Can't I be myself without you jumping in with your right and wrong? The world is not black and white. Show me one perfect person. If you can't, don't ask me to be.
Person2: I do have a right to ask you to be a little bit better than me and your father because we gave you a better head start. You have no right to complain to us about your not having enough.  You sit right there with your no manners self.

Person1: That's the whole point, Jeffrey. That's the whole point. Anyone's. Everyone's. They are gonna look under every rock, dig up every flaw, every mistake you've ever made. They are going to distort and exaggerate everything you've ever done, man. Don't you understand?
Person2: What does this have to do with my testimony?
Person1: That's not the point.
Person2: What does this have to do with my testimony?! I told the truth! It's valid and true and provable!
Person1: That's not the point, whether you told the truth or not! Hello...?
Person2: I told the truth... I told the truth.

Person1: This is just what they want, Buddy. Don't you see it?  They want to drive us apart.  To beat us.  We can't let them do it.  We've been through too much together, Buddy ... We belong together.
Person2: That's what you said the first time we met.  You didn't even know me.

Person1: No, Daddy. Our business is journalism. We can't continue to be so irresponsible . . . or else we'll just lead everyone into a disaster.

Person1: ...See you tomorrow night.

Person1: You don't mean that.  You wouldn't disappoint Daddy --
Person2: Daddy'll do fine.  Besides, he's got Joe.  And so do you.

Person2: That may be.  But I don't like that guy.  I don't like the way he looks at you and talks to you.  And vice versa.
Person1: Sorry, but I like the way he looks and talks to me.  And vice versa. Okay?
Person2: No, not okay.  I thought we had a good thing going here.  It shows you never know.

Person1: Sorry it took me so long on the phone. But we're all set.
Person2: All set for what?

Person2: Atlantic City?
Person1: I know it's a drag -- but you can't find a hotel room in town -- not on New Year's Eve.
Person2: Ring out the old year, ring in the new. Ring-a-ding-ding.
Person1: I didn't plan it this way, Fran -- actually, it's all Baxter's fault.
Person2: Baxter?
Person1: He wouldn't give me the key to the apartment.
Person2: He wouldn't.
Person1: Just walked out on me -- quit -- threw that big fat job right in my face.

Person2: I don't know. I guess that's the way it crumbles -- cookie-wise.
Person1: What are you talking about?
Person2: I'd spell it out for you -- only I can't spell.

Person1: Tell me what it was that gave me away. What was the piece of evidence you were going to use against me right before I walked up to YOU and put my hands in the air.

Person1: I don't think I can get her to do it.

Oh, by the way, you might want to take a look at these..if you have any further qualms about getting her to do the job.

Person1: You just relax. Nobody's killin' anybody, do you hear?

Person1: Mommy?  It's not Rachel's fault I ran away.
Person2: No, that's your fault.  It's her fault for not watching over my precious son, as if it were her priority.  Which means, the most important job.
Person1: Rachel's job is she works.
Person2: Ben, mommies work too.  They work very hard.  Mommy works harder as a mom than she did when she was working.  I just don't get paid.
Person1: Does Rachel make a lot of money?
Person2: People like Rachel who only think about themselves often do make a lot of money.
Person1: I think she's pretty, Mommy.
Person2: Yes...if you like big hair...
Person1: Mommy?
Person2: What honey?
Person1: If you want me to hate her I will.

Person1: Forget it. You're just all talk. So, when are you done with those meetin's?
Person2: Week after I'm twenty-one.
Person1: Are they hookin' you up with a job?
Person2: Yeah, sit in a room and do long division for the next fifty years.
Person1: Yah, but it's better than this shit. At least you'd make some nice bank.
Person2: Yeah, be a researcher.
Person1: It's a way outta here.
Person2: What do I want a way outta here for? I want to live here the rest of my life. I want to be your next door neighbor. I want to take out kids to little league together up Foley Field.
Person1: Look, you're my best friend, so don't take this the wrong way, but in 20 years, if you're living next door to me, coming over watching the Patriots' games and still working construction, I'll be really upset with you. And that's not a threat, that's a fact. I'll be really upset with you.
Person2: Chuckie, what are you talkin'...
Person1: Listen, you got somethin' that none of us have.
Person2: Why is it always this? I owe it to myself? What if I don't want to?
Person1: Forget you. You owe it to me. Tomorrow I'm gonna wake up and I'll be fifty and I'll still be doing this. And that's all right 'cause I'm gonna make a run at it. But you, you're sitting on a winning lottery ticket and you're too scared to cash it in. And that's nonsense 'cause I'd do anything to have what you got! And so would any of these guys. It'd be a real shame if you're still here in twenty years.
Person1: Let me tell you what I do know. Every day I come by to pick you up, and we go out drinkin' or whatever and we have a few laughs. But you know what the best part of my day is? The ten seconds before I knock on the door 'cause I let myself think I might get there, and you'd be gone. I'd knock on the door and you wouldn't be there. You just left.

Person1: I hate to turn on this light, you Daddy's awake downstairs, but I have to take the chance.  Buddy, please don't tell on me.
Person2: I said I wouldn't.
Person1: Buddy, I have to ask you, as bad as I've been please have pity on me and don't ruin me by telling them what I did. I know it was bad, it was bad and dumb. But mostly it was dumb, I didn't mean you no harm, I'd never want to hurt a hair on your head and that's the truth. I love you. But they'd think I did, they'd think I was awful, they'd despise me and hate me...

Person1: You said "the Commander.

Person1: Your sister said she didn't know where you were so you shouldn't write to her with return address if you're hiding.

Person1: Today, I'm offering you a lousy job at a lousy wage.  You think you're better than that?  Fine.  Show me.  Show me that you're really willing to change and we'll talk about something better. A lot better.  But first, Jack, you gotta earn it.
Person2: How, Dick?  The way you earned it?  By marrying some rich broad owns the company, selling it off a piece at a time, then divorcing her?  What is this Knute Rockne, pull yourself up by the bootstraps bullshit?  Back in prison, guy like you, place like that, you were ice cream for freaks.  You were a goddamn dumpling.  Maurice and a dozen other guys coulda bled you till you had nothing.  Till you were nothing.  I saved your ass.  So you'll pardon me if I don't wanna sit on a damn stool all day saying "sign in here please" or "hey, pal, you can't park there."  Okay, Dick?  I can't do it.
Person1: Jack, I'm disappointed.  I guess I misjudged you.

Person1: What about Elliot Harmsway? Or is this just another one of your stunts?
Person2: No! He's crazy - he's insane. He hates everybody. He's got these plans -  You've got to help me, James. I'm sorry. I'm sorry for everything. I know I was wrong - but you've got to protect me. I know you still love -

Person1: Jeanne... I believe in you -- but can you believe in me for once? Don't go... even if you don't want to marry me.
Person2: I would like to marry you.  But I have already promised myself... to God.
Person1: But... you've done so much for God as it is... can't you do something for yourself for once -- for Jeanne?
Person2: But it is what I want.
Person1: To be killed in battle?
Person2: If God wants me to win, he will find a way.  And if he wants me to die... if he wants me back... then that's fine too.  Then I'll be with him forever.

Person1: I just came to say goodbye.

Person1: Well, I'm afraid you don't have a choice in the matter. You make me sick. You're a hypocrite and I don't associate with hypocrites.

Person1: Outrageous.  I won't let you take control of my company.

Someone who has a way to dispose of the bodies. You have access, you can call up local authorities, check morgues, conduct interviews. Be my man.

Person1: Hello?
Person2: It's Daniel.
Person1: Daniel. Listen I'm afraid there has been a big--
Person2: -- I've got the tapes. If you ever want to see your brother out of jail do exactly what I say. Bring one million euros to your boat at six o'clock.
Person1: A million! I don't have that kind of money.
Person2: Don't bullshit me, Laurant!   I know about the Van Gogh.
Person1: I don't have it. That's why Vincent went to Chicago. They arrested him before he could bring it back.
Person2: Well, you better get the money somehow. Six o'clock and come alone. If you don't we'll destroy the tapes.

Person1: We have to have a plan.
Person2: What sort of plan?
Person1: Our children cannot see us die first. If the Militia comes, you must hurry up to the roof. I will meet you there.
Person2: Please do not talk like this.
Person1: We have to. If I do not come, you must take them all by the hands and jump.

Person1: Um...look, there's something I've, uh, that's been bothering me for a long time, and I just thought I'd just tell you what it was and just sort of clear the deck here, and  that's this.
Person2: Oh, yeah?  What?
Person1: That I've always regretted the way I behaved that evening we went out, and, uh...I've, I just thought I'd tell you that because I really made a fool out of myself.
Person2: Oh, don't be silly!  No!  Don't be ridiculous.
Person1: It's all right.
Person2: I was the, I was... You know, it was my fault.  I--

Person1: Where did you get these?

Person1: What do you want from me?
Person2: Strength. Westerburg doesn't need mushy togetherness, it needs a leader. Heather Chandler was that leader but...
Person1: But she couldn't handle it.

Person1: Oh, it's nothing... I better go, I'll talk to you later.
Person2: Ok, have fun there, you're so lucky you don't have any kids yet and you can go off to Japan... call me when you get back.

Person1: Runnin' off and worryin' people. Makin' it tougher on Clay than it is already.
Person2: Don't ask me because I won't tell you! I won't tell anybody! Go away!
Person1: Don't act so -- crazy.
Person2: I'm sorry. Let's go.
Person1: That's a good girl.

Person1: And you had a sister who died in the convent.

Person1: Do you still go to church?
Person2: What business is it of yours..?
Person1: Oh, we just wonder if you can be very objective about this case.
Person2: Look, Father, ah... just because I don't subscribe to the... to the beliefs you subscribe to...
Person1: But what you believe makes no difference to us whatsoever Doctor. But it does make all the difference to Agnes.
Person2: I don't understand. Are you expecting me to..?

Person1: Will? Are you awake?
Person2: No.
Person1: Come with me to California.
Person2: What?
Person1: I want you to come with me.
Person2: How do you know that?
Person1: I know. I just do.
Person2: Yeah, but how do you know?
Person1: I don't know. I just feel it.
Person2: And you're sure about that?
Person1: Yeah, I'm sure.
Person2: 'Cause that's a serious thing you're sayin'. I mean, we might be in California next week and you could find out somethin' about me that you don't like. And you might feel like "hey this is a big mistake."  But you can't take it back, 'cause you know it's real serious and you can't take somethin' like that back. Now I'm in California, 'cause you asked me to come. But you don't really want me there. And I'm stuck in California with someone who really doesn't want me there and just wishes they had a take-back.
Person1: "Take-back?" What is that? I don't want a take-back. I want you to come to California with me.
Person2: I can't go out to California.
Person1: Why not?
Person2: One, because I have a job here and two because I live here--
Person1: Look, Will if you're not in love with me, you can say that.
Person2: I'm not sayin' I'm not in love with you.
Person1: Then what are you afraid of?
Person2: What do you mean "What am I afraid of?"
Person1: Why won't you come with me? What are you so scared of?
Person2: What am I scared of?
Person1: Well, what aren't you scared of? You live in your safe little world where nobody challenges you and you're scared shitless to do anything else--
Person2: --Don't tell me about my world. You're the one that's afraid. You just want to have your little fling with the guy from the other side of town and marry--
Person1: Is that what you think--
Person2: --some prick from Stanford that your parents will approve of. Then you'll sit around with the rest of the upper crust kids and talk about how you went slummin' too.
Person1: I inherited that money when I was thirteen, when my father died.
Person2: At least you have a mother.
Person1: Screw you! You think I want this? That money's a burden to me. Every day I wake up and I wish I could give that back. I'd give everything I have back to spend one more day with my father. But that's life. And I deal with it. So don't put that shit on me. You're the one that's afraid.
Person2: What am I afraid of?!
Person1: You're afraid of me. You're afraid that I won't love you back. And guess what? I'm afraid too. But at least I have the balls to it give it a shot. At least I'm honest with you.
Person2: I'm not honest?
Person1: What about your twelve brothers?
Person2: Oh, is that what this is about? You want to hear that I don't really have any brothers? That I'm a orphan? Is that what you want to hear?
Person1: Yes, Will. I didn't even know that?
Person2: No, you don't want to hear that.
Person1: Yes, I do, Will.
Person2: You don't want to hear that I got cigarettes put out on me when I was a little kid. That this isn't surgery

Person1: -- And what did Dr. Paley do after you stopped seeing him?
Person2: He used to call me -- tell me that I couldn't just walk out on him.  He said that if I didn't come back he'd make my life miserable.
Person1: Did he make your life miserable?
Person2: Yes -- he did.
Person1: How?

Person1: I'm sorry about getting on your case earlier.  I just see you getting sucked in deeper and deeper, and I -- anyway.  I'm sorry.
Person2: S'okay.  I know you still love me.

Person1: You still haven't kissed her yet ? Don't lie.
Person2: What's the hurry ?
Person1: Others are waiting.

Person1: So what's going on, Joel?
Person2: I don't know, I've just been thinking, maybe we're not happy with each other.
Person1: What?
Person2: Y'know, we've been, I don't know, sort of, unhappy with each other and --
Person1: Don't say "we" when you mean "you."
Person2: I think maybe, we're both so used to operating at this level that -- How can one person be unhappy? If one person is unhappy, both have to be... by definition.
Person1: Bullshit. Who is it? You met someone.
Person2: No. I just need some space, maybe.
Person1: The thing is, Joel, whatever it is you think you have with this chick, once the thrill wears off, you're just going to be Joel with the same problems.
Person2: It's not somebody else.

Person1: You're all just jealous.
Person2: Actually, I have no idea what the World's Record is.  I was just kidding.

Person1: These new people never identified themselves.  They musta been watching the whole thing 'cause they knew everything Mary and me had been doing that day.  I guess I wasn't too hard to find - wearing that red raincoat.
Person2: How many shots you say you heard?
Person1: Four to six.
Person2: That's impossible.  You heard echoes ...echoes.  We have three bullets and three shots which came from the Book Depository and that's all we're willing to say.
Person1: ...which is strange 'cause this is less than 20 minutes after the assassination.
Person1: No, I saw a guy shooting from over there.  He was behind that fence. What are you going to do about it?
Person2: We have that taken care of.  You only heard three shots and you are not to talk to anyone about this. No one, you hear?
Person1: I was scared.  It was all kinda queer, but it sure felt like two and two was coming up three... and then they took Mary's five snapshots from me, sent them to Washington, and when they returned them weeks later, two of them had the backgrounds mutilated... The only one we saved was in Mary's camera.  I didn't want to go to Washington when the Warren Commission subpoenaed me... so the lawyer come down here and interviewed me at Parkland Hospital.

Person1: Paula, how far would you go to catch Zack?

After that I figure she'll tell the Police that you broke in.  That you were crazed because we humiliated you in court?

Person1: An atomic bomb.

Young trophy wife, I mean, in the parlance of our times, owes money all over town, including to known pornographers-- and that's cool, that's cool-- but I'm saying, she needs money, and of course they're gonna say they didn't get it 'cause she wants more, man, she's gotta feed the monkey, I mean-- hasn't that ever occurred to you...? If it weren't for him, I would have been out of here long ago, but he always stops me. Six months ago, I tried to escape and he locked me in a dark room. I nearly went crazy.  Look at me, Mr. Conway, do I look like an old woman? Is this the skin of an old woman? Look into my eyes and see if these are the eyes of an old woman?

Person1: Let me guess--breakfast is served?
Person2: No.
Person1: What then?
Person2: I do not wish to be scrogged--ever. I never heard that word, but when I heard it, I knew it was one thing I never wanted to have happen to me.
Person1: That's what you're supposed to say.
Person2: This is not a coy deception.  I do not want to be scrogged.  I want love.  I want tenderness.
Person1: You don't know you want.  That's the way God built you!
Person2: I will not be scrogged.  I remember one time I saw you wrench a hook from the throat of a fish with a pair of pliers, and you promised me that the fish couldn't feel.
Person1: It couldn't!
Person2: I'd like to have the expert opinion of the fish--along with yours.
Person1: Fish can't feel.
Person2: Well, I can.  Some injuries, spiritual or physical, can be excruciating to me.  I'm not a silly carhop any more.  Maybe you're right about fish. When I was a carhop, I didn't feel much more than a fish would.  But I've been sensitized.  I have ideas now--and solid information.  I know a lot more now--and a lot of it has to do with you.
Person1: Such as?...
Person2: The whole concept of heroism--and its sexual roots.
Person1: Tell me about its sexual roots.
Person2: It's complicated and I don't want to go into it now, because it's bound to sound insulting--even though nobody means for anybody to be insulted.  It's just the truth.
Person1: I like the truth.  I wouldn't be alive today if I weren't one of the biggest fans truth ever had.
Person2: Well--part of it is that heroes basically hate home and never stay there very long, and make awful messes while they're there.
Person1: Go on.
Person2: And they have very mixed feelings about women.  They hate them in a way.  One reason they like war so much is that they can capture enemy women and not have to make love to them slowly and gently.  They can scrog them, as you say--  for revenge.
Person1: You learned this in some college course?
Person2: I learned a lot of things in college.  Actually--it was Norbert who told me that.
Person1: The doctor.
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And what is his most cherished possession?
Person2: His most cherished possession?  His violin, I guess.
Person1: And he keeps it in his apartment?
Person2: Yes.
Person1: And no one's there now?
Person2: I don't think so.
Person1: That's too bad.  I would rather have him at home--to see what I'm going to do.
Person2: What are you going to do?
Person1: He did his best to destroy my most precious possession, which is the high opinion women have of me.  I'm now going to even that score.  I'm going to break in his door and I'm going to smash his violin.
Person2: No you're not!
Person1: Why not?
Person2: Because if you do--I'll leave you. HAROLD  Goodbye.

Person1: I can't believe you're making this up - it sounds like something out of an old Clyde Fitch play...

Person2: I don't think that's funny!
Person1: Of course it's funny - this is all too laughable to be anything else. You know what I think about this - this age obsession of yours - and now this ridiculous attempt to whip yourself up into a jealous froth because I spent ten minutes with a stage-struck kid-
Person2: Twenty minutes!
Person1: Thirty minutes, forty minutes! What of it?
Person2: Stage-struck kid... she's a young lady - of qualities. And I'll have you know I'm fed up with both the young lady and her qualities! Studying me as if - as if I were a play or a set of blueprints! How I walk, talk, think, eat, sleep!
Person1: Now how can you take offense at a kid trying in every way to be as much like her ideal as possible!
Person2: Stop calling her a kid! It so happens there are particular aspects of my life to which I would like to maintain sole and exclusive rights and privileges!
Person1: For instance what?
Person2: For instance - you!
Person1: This is my cue to take you in my arms and reassure you - but I'm not going to. I'm too mad-
Person2: - guilty.
Person1: Mad! Darling, there are certain characteristics for which you are famous - on stage and off. I love you for some of them - and in spite of others. I haven't let those become too important to me. They're part of your equipment for getting along in what is laughably called out environment - you've got to keep your teeth sharp. All right. But you will not sharpen them on me - or on Eve...
Person2: What about her teeth? What about her fangs?
Person1: She hasn't cut them yet, and you know it! So when you start judging an idealistic dreamy-eyed kid by the barroom, Benzedrine standards of this megalomaniac society - I won't have it! Eve Harrington has never by word, look, thought or suggestion indicated anything to me but her adoration for you and her happiness at our being in love! And to intimate anything else doesn't spell jealousy to me - it spells a paranoic insecurity that you should be ashamed of!
